MEMO:

At a conference between Rev. Dr. Sutherland, Rev. Mr. Perrier and the Supt. of Indian Education, it was urged that new day school buildings be erected at Kishpiak and Clayoquot. $500 is estimated as the cost of a day school at Clayoquot and about $900 at Kishpiak.

Ottawa, 18th October, 1906.
Department of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, Oct 27, 19--

To be dealt with after Shute's death, twenty years hence.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter # 327, dated the 21st of December last, bringing to my notice that within the last few years sundry requests for Indian Day School buildings within the limits of this Agency had been made to your Office and by it, from time to time as received, forwarded to the Department, and in particular in reference to the localities of Babine, New Kitegukla and Kispiax.

Thereby am I also asked to renew the application dealing with each in a separate communication, and that each application should specify all the particulars desired by the Department.

In regard to the aforementioned, I have the honour to enclose herewith the requisite papers in connection with the proposed School Building at Kispiax,

to wit:-

A plan regarding ground floor (drawn to scale)
do " elevation ( )
and a specification in respect to the necessary material, etc.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

A. W. VOWELL, ESQ.
Indian Agent.

Superintendent of Indian Affairs, B.C., &c.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 13th of December last in regard to the subject of the numerous requests made by several of the Agents throughout the Superintendency for new Bay School buildings, I have the honour to enclose herewith for the Department's information and consideration an application of the 14th ultimo to-day received from Mr. Agent Loring of the Babine Agency renewing the request for a new school building at Kispiax.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,-

In adverting to your letter File No.139209/5, dated the 7th of April last, and mine of the 6th ultimo, regarding the Kispiox school building, and the cheque of $300.00 forwarded, and its ceiling to be 12 feet in height instead of 10 feet, I have the honour to state that on the plan submitted it was omitted to give the particulars in that the walls were 10 feet, and the extra extent of 2 feet more to the ceiling were to be derived to the following effect,

to wit:-

and hope that in that shape an alteration would not be necessary in the height of the walls, since the 12 feet high ceiling is gained by 2 feet of a bevel, and would improve the acoustic qualities of the room.

In regard the progress, I here beg leave to state that a considerable amount of the material is on the ground, and, in so far, on the 2nd instant I made the first payment in regard the latter, i.e., $7.75 for 31 foundation posts @ 25¢ each.

I presume that in that respect the expenses incurred, must consecutively be treated by vouchers, periodically, for the months wherein respectively, incurred.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
OTTAWA, June 7, 1940.

SIR,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th ultimo in reference to the erection of a school on the Kisiplax reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to know that a suitable site has been selected and trusts that the building when completed will be a credit to all interested.

It is quite recognized that there has been some increase in the cost of material since the estimate originally furnished of the cost of this building was made and it is also considered necessary to make the alterations suggested by the Department in letter of April 7th, last. As the work progresses you will be in a position to judge whether the building can be satisfactorily completed for the sum of $1000.00 which was allowed, but if this is not found to be sufficient a larger expenditure should not be incurred without authority.

Your obedient servant,

SECRETARY.

R. W. Loring, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Nazleton, B.C.
Babine and Upper Skeena River Agency,

Hazelton, B.C., May 6th 1919.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,-

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, No.139209/5, dated the 7th ultimo, stating that Mr. Vowell had forwarded to the Department my letter of 14th of February last, renewing the request for a day school building at Kispiax, and enclosing a sketch and detailed estimate of the amount and cost of material and furnishings, and the cost of labour. Also is it remarked that the Department had decided to authorize me to proceed with the erection of this building, but wishes certain changes made in the plan. In that in the first place it is thought that the room should be no less than twelve feet in height, and not ten as shown on my plan. Also that separate closets with screened approaches should be provided, and that they should be placed at a suitable distance from the rear of the building. And that a door should also be provided between the wood-shed and the porch. Likewise is it stated that no provision had been made in my estimates for painting, and that this should be arranged for.

Also is my attention directed to the matter of requiring a careful consideration as to the site. In that the latter be high and dry, and that there should be sufficient area to permit of gardening operations being carried on, if the soil be at all suitable, and to report on these latter conditions.

Furthermore, the Department states that it has every confidence
confidence that the erection of this building will receive my best supervision and that, when completed, it will be satisfactory to all concerned, and a credit to the Department and the Agency, and to report when operations commence and from time to time during progress.

Also alluding to the changes referred to that they will add somewhat to the cost, but if a good job were done the Department will be satisfied, if the expenditure is kept within the sum of $1000.00. And in order that I may not be in any way handicapped by lack of funds an accountable cheque for $300.00 is sent me therewith; and that these funds should be used to pay for labour and material as required, and when Vouchers, properly certified, are received showing an expenditure to that extent a further advance would be sent.

In regard the foregoing, to report on certain conditions, I beg leave to state that the site for the school building has long ago been selected, and is on an high and dry plateau back of the village and central thereto. The soil is fair, and can easily be improved upon. The environs of the site permit of gardening being carried on.

In respect to the extra cost of the proposed changes in the plan, painting, etc., the cost will further be augmented by the difference in the price of lumber when the application for the building was made and present conditions. In the latter respect it stands:

| Description          | Per M. | Present Price |
|----------------------|--------|---------------|
| Heretofore, Rough Lumber | $14.00 | $25.00        |
| Rustic               | $20.00 | $30.00        |
| Tongue and Grooved   | $20.00 | $32.00        |
| Dressed & Shiplap    | $20.00 | $26.00        |

Though, for all that, the liberal provision for the purpose may
may be made to meet the expenses with the exercise of great care and circumspection.

In concluding, I beg leave to add that the foundation logs for the building are already ordered, and upon the same being delivered the ground will be prepared and progress made.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Sir,

Mr. Vowell has forwarded to the Department your letter of the 14th of February, last, renewing the request for a day school building at Kishpias and enclosing a sketch and detailed estimate of the amount and cost of material and furnishings and the cost of labour.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has decided to authorize you to proceed with the erection of this building, but wishes certain changes made in the plan.

In the first place it is thought that the room should be not less than twelve feet in height, not ten as shown on your plan. Separate closets with screened approaches should be provided and they should be placed at a suitable distance from the rear of the building. A door should also be provided between the wood-shed and the porch. No provision is made in your estimates for painting and this should be arranged for.

Another matter requiring careful consideration is the site. This should be high and dry and there should be sufficient area to permit of gardening operations being carried on, if the soil is at all suitable. Be good enough to report on this.

The Department has every confidence that the

Memorandum:

Re new school building.

Inspector Green reports under date of July, 1909 that "There is no school house, an Indian Epworth League Hall being used. The Indians occupy the room every evening, and this makes it very inconvenient for the school.

A new building suitable for sixty pupils is urgently required. I would very respectfully recommend that such be erected as soon as possible."

Department advised Supt. Vowell under date of October 5, 1909 to include an application for a new building in his next estimates. The estimate of $900 was placed for the suggested new building at a Conference between Rev. Dr. Sutherland and Rev. Mr. Perrier and the Supt. of Indian Education - see Mr. Scott's memo. of 18th October, 1909. (File No.139,269/5)
Ottawa, 9th December, 1910.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th October last, with which you enclosed a statement account of expenses incurred in the erection of the Kispiox Day School building.

You stated therein that the work was progressing satisfactorily and that a full report would shortly follow. As this has not yet come to hand, I have to ask you to forward such at your early convenience.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R. E. Loring, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.
BRITISH COLUMBIA,
BABINE AGENCY,

File No.139208/5

Hazelton, January 3rd 1911.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,-

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, dated the 9th ultimo, with reference to mine of the 5th October last, with which I enclosed a Statement Account, at that time, of expenses incurred in the erection of the Kispiax Day School building, and am reminded that then I mentioned that a full report thereon soon would follow.

In regard to the foregoing, I beg leave to state that that building - according to the specifications - is all complete and finished in every respect but to the paint yet to be applied.

On somewhat improvised benches, school has been taught therein since the middle of last November.

I here must declare that, upon inspection, the said School building will stand as a credit to the Department, and to the Indian labour in construction, of which, one George Williams, of Kispiax, was foreman. It shows thorough workmanship, in carpentry, in every feature. The doors are made to swing outward, and everything else is perfect in connection therewith.

On an opportunity offering, I intend to procure thereof a photograph, for the Department, depicting the building's full appearance in conjunction with the most favourable site chosen for the purpose.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 13, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd ultimo, and in reply I beg to say that the Department is very pleased to know that the new Kishpax day school building is about completed and that the work has been done in such a satisfactory manner.

The Department will be very glad to have a photograph of this building so that a cut may appear in the next annual report.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. T. Loring, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Voucher No.43, for $519.05, which includes a small balance of cheque No.2, for $300.00, dated the 11th of April last, and the whole of cheque No.1847, dated October 21st last, also for $300.00, for advance in defraying the building of an Indian School House, at Kispiax, and giving the amount $19.05, advanced by the Hudson's Bay Company, in order, to meet all the bills presented, up to date, in regard thereto.

Likewise is that Voucher accompanied by a balance sheet in connection therewith.

At the same time, I find myself impelled to request herewith the transmission of another cheque of that denomination, wherewith to meet other outstanding accounts. The bills for lumber, furnished for the said School House have not yet been presented, and they will more than absorb the amount applied for herein. The Manager of the Kispiax saw mill is absent, and the extent of those bills cannot at present be ascertained. The hope that he may return in a reasonable time, somewhat occasioned the delay of this letter.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of the letter, dated the 10th ultimo, stating that Mr. Inspector Green in his last report referred to the splendid workmanship on the new building on the Kispiox reserve, and had stated that the seats and desks were just rough boards, and looked out of place in the new school-house, and the query is put: "would it be possible to have these desks planed and painted?"

In reference thereto I must point to the contents of my letter, dated the 8th of April last, and enclosed therewith Voucher No.79, and statement account, covering the expenditure of $300.00 in connection with the building of that school by Cheque No.2554, for that amount, and quoting my remark therewith:—"I here beg to state that remains yet to be paid a balance on lumber for $130.97—and on a very close estimate, the purchase of paint and its application will be $160.00, totalling $290.97, and request that that amount be forwarded with which to complete that account."

In regard thereto would add that the longer the painting be deferred, the more paint it will require, and the more defective it will be on the building, and that an additional sum of $10.00 can be made to cover the planing and painting of the desks and benches referred to.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Day School Porch & Woodshed.

Further to our conversation of even date re above,

1. Some time ago the tar-paper roofing of the porch was torn off in a gale and as a result the porch is flooded in wet weather. Measurements show that five rolls of tar-paper would repair the damage done.

2. The woodshed which is on the east side of the school is open to the weather. I understand that the snow drifts into the woodshed, almost completely filling it and making it necessary to dig the wood out from under the snow. This also takes from the effectiveness of our one stove. I would suggest that a dividing wooden door, about ten feet by eight feet, be constructed to remedy this defect.

3. The putty has perished and fallen away from several of the panes of glass in the windows. I believe that five pounds of putty judiciously used now would save the Department the very much larger expenditure which is likely to be incurred if any of these large panes are blown out and broken, which is liable to happen in stormy weather.

I shall be grateful if you will kindly obtain authority for expenditure on these materials and for the necessary labour involved in their use.

Very truly yours,

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Day School Porch & Woodshed.

Further to our conversation of even date re above,

1. Some time ago the tar-paper roofing of the porch was torn off in a gale and as a result the porch is flooded in wet weather. Measurements show that five rolls of tar-paper would repair the damage done.

2. The woodshed which is on the east side of the school is open to the weather. I understand that the snow drifts into the woodshed, almost completely filling it and making it necessary to dig the wood out from under the snow. This also takes from the effectiveness of our one stove. I would suggest that a dividing wooden door, about ten feet by eight feet, be constructed to remedy this defect.

3. The putty has perished and fallen away from several of the panes of glass in the windows. I believe that five pounds of putty judiciously used now would save the Department the very much larger expenditure which is likely to be incurred if any of these large panes are blown out and broken, which is liable to happen in stormy weather.

I shall be grateful if you will kindly obtain authority for expenditure on these materials and for the necessary labour involved in their use.

Very truly yours,

J. J. Burchell.

Dear Sir:

At the meeting of the Prince Rupert Presbytery in this city yesterday, the members were unanimous in the feeling that steps should be taken almost immediately to provide the workers at Kispiox with a well and pump in close proximity to the buildings. This accommodation would not only greatly add to their comfort and convenience but would also in case of fire provide greater safety for life and property.

As you doubtless know, water for drinking, cooking and washing now has to be carried two hundred yards or more and that task, in the winter when the river and the distant springs are frozen over with a foot or two of solid ice and snow, is no mean task.

It was thought that $100 would cover the cost of digging and cribbing the well and providing a force pump for the same and I was asked to write you in the hope that the Indian Department, being interested in the situation, would provide half that amount, on condition that our Mission Board will take care of the other half. Knowing your great interest in all efforts for the unsalvation of the Indian people I am sure you will give this proposal your unqualified support.

Dear Sirs:

As you are aware, the securing of water for the missionary-teacher's residence at Kispiox has been a problem for some years. Last year the Department, on the recommendation of Mr. Indian Agent Mortimer, made two grants of $20.00 and $25.00, and the United Church voted similar amounts—a total of $150.00 in all—to dig a well and provide a pump.

I am just in receipt of the following telegram:

"BURCHILL REPORTS SIX INCHES WATER AT THIRTY-SEVEN FEET ONE HUNDRED FIFTY GRANT EXHAUSTED EXPERIMENTED MINER RECOMMENDS CONTINUANCE DEFERRED INDICATIONS OF CLAY IN GRAVEL GATE-IN BOULDER AGAIST CRIBBING MAKES READING EXCAVATION MORE EXPENSIVE."

Now, that we have spent so much money on this project, it seems too bad not to complete it. Will the Department of Indian Affairs advance another $50.00, with the understanding that a similar amount is to be contributed by the United Church?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

KJB

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, requesting that this Department provide a further grant, to the amount of $50.00, towards the cost of obtaining a water supply for use of the Kispiox Indian Day School and mission house, and embodying copy of a telegram which you received regarding the matter.

In view of the need of completing the project in deepening the well and repairing the gridding, in order that an adequate supply of water can be obtained for use of the school, the Department will allow a further advance of $50.00 towards the cost, on the understanding that a similar amount will be contributed by the United Church authorities. Dear Sir:

The Department is informed, by the authorities of the United Church of Canada, that it will be necessary to incur further expenditure in deepening and cribbing the well at the Kispick Indian Day School, in order to secure an adequate supply of water.

As you are aware, the Department has already contributed certain of the costs of digging and cribbing the well. In this connection I would refer you to official letter dated September 4th, 1935. The Church authorities now request that the Department advance a further sum of $50.00 towards the cost of obtaining an adequate water supply, on the understanding that a similar amount is to be contributed by the United Church authorities. The Department is informing the church authorities that a further sum of $50.00 will be provided towards the cost of placing the well in a serviceable condition.

After the work has been completed, you should forward a voucher, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the entire cost of the labour and materials, and, upon receipt of this voucher, the Department will provide payment to the amount of $50. Dear Sir,

In reply to Mr. Philip Phelan's letter of July 6th I wish to advise you that detailed particulars regarding the erection of a second room to the present Kispiox Indian Day School have been forwarded to the Indian Commissioner for B.C. for submission to, and consideration by, the Department.

I am fully of the opinion that there will be often an attendance of 65 to 70 pupils at the Kispiox School during the coming academic year. The present room has been overcrowded during the past year with a frequent attendance of 55 to 60 pupils and, on account of the expected increase in September, I do recommend a second teacher and a second room for this school - if the Department can see its way to grant same.

Some new desks would be necessary together with a teacher's table, heater and other small articles. However, these may be dealt with at a later date.

I may say that the suggested alterations to the wood shed were found unsatisfactory and the estimates already submitted are for a second room to be erected at the opposite end of the school and will be in alignment with the present building.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re- Indian Day School, Kispiox Reserve.

As the school term is nearly over, I feel it is an opportune time to bring to your notice, the inadequate condition of the present Indian Day School buildings on the Kispiox Reserve.

From September 1937, the number of pupils have greatly increased, and there now 60 on the roll, with an average attendance of 45 to 50, of course there several children under school age, however further children will be enrolled when the school opens in September.

On my inspection visits I found the pupils greatly cramped for room, on several single seats two children were seated, it would be impossible to put further seats in the building, however if the building was extended it would eliminate the present congested situation.

The size of the school at present is as follows 31 feet long by 24 feet wide, this length could be increased by taking in the woodshed, giving a total of 41 by 24, this could be done at a reasonable cost.

Should the Department desire to enlarge this school, I could get an estimate on material required, labour could be done by efficient Indian carpenters, under my own supervision.

Your obedient Servant,

Dear Sir:

I have a letter from Rev. D.W. More, B.A., of Hazelton B.C., recently nominated by our Church as Missionary-teacher for Kishpiox, and duly ratified by your Department at Ottawa. I advised him to visit Kishpiox and look over the ground and report to me his findings; consequently I have this letter from him dated May 25th in which he says that he visited the school, now conducted by Miss Bews, who seems to be doing good work there but will need to be changed because the work requires an ordained minister and she went only as supply to the end of the school term.

Mr. More reports that on examining the roll of the school, there were on the roll 65 pupils, with a prospect of further increase this coming term. The maximum attendance at the present time is 48 and there were about fifty days with over 40 present at the school. Mr. More comments that these are significant figures, especially in view of the fact that most of the pupils are in grades 1, 2 and 3. To quote from his letter -

"It means that the extra individual attention always necessary in those grades and especially in view of the language difficulty is impossible....It means also that the variety of presentation of lessons in the older grades that would make the work attractive to older scholars is also impossible - a further cause of many failing to continue above the primary grades. These might be attracted to school again if an additional room were provided. None of the present enrolment should leave school this year, and when there is a considerable number which should commence, the situation will be seriously aggravated next fall. Expansion of the building is at least imperative, and if the Indian Department is willing to do that, perhaps they could be induced to go the whole way and add another room. The school is very promising and it would be a shame if it should suffer a set back from overcrowding just when so many of the pupils and parents are showing a real interest."
Captain Mortimer, he says, is all in favour of two rooms there and he believes Captain Barry is also favourable. He further states:

"In my opinion this is a golden opportunity to put the school on an entirely new and higher basis in the Community."

Mr. More, I may add, was an experienced public school teacher in British Columbia before he entered the Ministry of the United Church and we are looking for excellent results from his services at Kishpox and especially so if the Department will take up the question of the necessary accommodation required for that large Indian village.

Thanking you for your early consideration of this matter,

I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

"S.S. Osterhout"
Superintendent of Missions

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant with reference to the Kispiox Indian Day School. I have also received recently Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of this school on October 17.

No funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the salary of a second teacher at this school and consequently the Department is unable to favourably consider the renting of an Indian house and the employment of a second teacher from January 1, 1939.

On August 3 last Indian Commissioner MacKay wrote to the Department in connection with the proposed addition to the Kispiox School. He was advised at that time that no provision for any expenditure of this nature had been made in the current year's appropriation. However, in preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40 it was found possible to include the amount that Indian Commissioner MacKay stated would be required to erect an addition. You should, therefore, write to the Department for further instructions in June next and arrangements will be made at that time for building the addition during the months of July and August.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

G. C. Mortimer, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B. C.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir,

re - Kispiox Indian Day School.

I am in receipt of a copy of School Inspector G.M. Barry's report regarding conditions at the Kispiox Indian Day School during his inspection in October, 1938.

I fully concur with what Inspector Barry states regarding insufficient room at this school to accommodate all the children of school age. A report was forwarded to the Department, dated July 13th last, file S-1C-56, giving an estimate of the number of school-age pupils that would be in attendance during the present academic year.

Since Inspector Barry's visit I have visited the Kispiox Reserve on several occasions and the chief complaint I have received from the Indians is the lack of school accommodation. Quite a number of parents have asked to have their children sent to the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School because of this condition.

May I suggest that the Department favourably consider Inspector Barry's remarks regarding the renting of a nearby Indian house, which can be procured at $6.00 per month, and the appointment of the teacher he recommends - Miss Bews - to commence on January 1st, 1939?

I would appreciate an early reply and full instructions if this matter is favourably received.

GCM/SM.

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Mortimer,

Dear Sir,

re - New School Bell for Kispiox Day School.

Mr. Hoey's

In reply to your letter of June 14th with reference to a new school bell for the Kispiox Indian Day School I wish to advise you that the village of Kispiox is very extensive and that a bell of good size, which can be heard at each extremity of the village, is necessary,- one of the "tower" type as distinguished from the "hand" type.

The Rev. D. W. More, teacher, informs me that the one mentioned in his requisition is the smallest size listed in the catalogue in his possession, but perhaps the Department could obtain a smaller one of the required type which would answer the purpose.

Mr. More rings the bell one half hour before school opens in the morning and ten minutes before the afternoon session.

Your obedient servant,

S. Mallinson,

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Departmental file 151-12-5
and your 15/1/5458 I have as requested read a letter C-1C-88
from the Acting Indian Agent at Hazelton and would report
as follows:

In my last report on the Kispiox Indian Day
School dated October 22nd 1938, I suggested on pages 2 and 3
that a house might be rented near the school to provide for
the Primary Grades. The Department did not accept this
suggestion. I also suggested that within a short time it
would be necessary to add a second classroom to the present
Kispiox Indian Day School, to accommodate the increased
attendance at that point.

This school is not one of those to be greatly
affected, if affected at all, by the proposed distribution
of pupils from Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.
There is however a very large attendance at the present time
and the total registration this year has been around 70, a
number far too great for one teacher. To accommodate the
children it has been necessary to somewhat cut short the
usual hours for the older pupils and to permit the youngest
children to attend only from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. These
temporary arrangements are not satisfactory to the parents,
as was explained on page 3 of my last report.

The suggested possible extension of 16 feet
to the present school would be more than a waste of money
as sufficient accommodation could not be provided for the
increasing attendance at Kispiox. The only possible
arrangement for a permanent solution of the problem here is
the suggested extension of the present school by 32 feet, and
I wish to recommend that such an extension be carried out as
soon as possible, provided there are any funds for such a
purpose. I certainly agree with the Acting Indian Agent
that the larger room or addition be erected in preference to
the smaller at the cost of even a year's delay in the work.

The Acting Indian Agent suggests that the sum
of $795.30 would cover the cost of the material and that
$875.00 would cover the labor. If such a sum of around $800.00
would cover the material I believe the Department would be well
advised to set aside at least another $400.00 to $500.00 for
labor and some $250.00 for desks and equipment. In my opinion
not less than $1,500.00 might be included in the 1940-41
Estimates for the purpose of adding and equipping a second
room at the Kispiox Indian Day School. I do not see how the
work could be carried out this year if such a sum as I have
suggested has not been provided in the 1939-40 Estimates.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir,

re - New Classroom for Kispiox Indian Day School.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's letter of November 26th, 1936, and your letter of August 19th, 1936, I wish to advise you that I have received estimates for the material required to build an additional classroom to the present Kispiox Indian Day School from Messrs R.J. Sargent, Ltd., Hazelton, the only local firm that supplies lumber. These estimates, which I enclose in triplicate, are for extensions of eighteen (18) and thirty-two (32) feet respectively, amounting to $494.83 and $795.30 - for material only. The approximate cost of labour on the above would be $200.00 and $275.00, respectively.

I made a thorough investigation regarding this extension and, in consultation with the Rev. D. W. More and Mr. Sargent, it was found that thirty-two feet added to the present school - which is also thirty-two feet - would be of far greater advantage and more in alignment with the present building than the smaller room. At the same time the number of pupils on this reserve, which is increasing yearly, should be taken into consideration. If the larger room could be built, the windows would all be on the one long side of the old and new buildings, whereas in the smaller room the windows would have to be at the end of the building, in order to conserve floor space for the desks.

When the Estimates for 1939-1940 were submitted, the amount entered for this addition was in connection with the alteration of a lean-to and woodshed, which would have given - at the most - an extension of twelve feet. This suggestion was not feasible and the amount inadequate for a properly built classroom. May I mention that the cost of the addition of twelve feet to the same classroom at Kitegukla was $566.30 where the width was only eighteen feet, compared to a width of twenty-five feet at Kispiox?

May I suggest that, if at all possible, the larger classroom be added to the Kispiox Day School?

Regarding the present Kispiox Day School Building it was found that all the cedar posts had rotted, numbering 24. These should be replaced before the new classroom is commenced. The cost, including labour, would be approximately $20.00.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P. O. Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

S. Mallinson,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to requisitions recently forwarded for supplies for the Kispiox Indian Day School, you may purchase the articles shown on the attached requisition.

I am also in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, in reference to the request that you have received for an expenditure not exceeding $200.00 for painting the exterior of the Kispiox School. As you are aware, our appropriation this year has been kept to the minimum and in preparing our estimates it was only possible to include an amount of $200.00 for repairs and painting that might be required at all the schools in the Babine agency. It is quite possible that the Kispiox School is in the worst condition, and the Department has no objection to painting the exterior of this school, provided it is distinctly understood by the Indian Agent that if a total of $200 is spent it will require the full amount that is available. In the event of your proceeding with this work you may arrange for the purchase of the paint required, as shown in the attached letter, and when forwarding the account, a copy of your purchase order should be attached.

Dear Sir,

re- Heater for Kispiox School.

On the attached requisition submitted by Rev. D.W. More, Principal of the Kispiox Indian Day School, entry is made for a new heater.

May I ask your advice as to the most suitable kind of heater for school purposes?

Most of the Day Schools in this Agency have been provided with Camp Comfort heaters, which radiate heat in the near vicinity, much to the discomfort of the scholars in those areas, but do not throw sufficient heat to the far corners of the school rooms.

A few years ago the school inspector recommended a Circulatory heater for one Day School in this Agency, but on account of the cost the Indian Agent did not apply for one and such heater was not considered suitable for the severe winter climate of this part.

Kispiox school building is the most up-to-date and the newest in this Agency and I would like to obtain the most suitable equipment for it. I may say that there are approximately 9000 cubic feet of space in the room for which this heater is required, and on a few occasions the temperature at this village has dropped to fifty degrees below zero.

Yours faithfully,

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

Enclosure.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Boys' letter of May 21st in connection with a proposed expenditure of $44.00 for repairs to the bell used at the Kispiox School and erection of a stage from which to suspend the bell. This matter was left in abeyance pending investigation by the School Inspector who now reports that the bell, although the property of the Band, was apparently broken while being used for school purposes, and that it served a very useful purpose in arousing the village and getting the pupils to school on time. Subject to the Indians agreeing to the use of the bell for school purposes for so long as it may be required it is recommended that the Department approve an expenditure of $44.00 for repairs and the erection of the staging.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Babine Agency

Hazelton, B.C. May 21, 1947

Major D.M. McKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

The Reverend R. Morris has approached me regarding repairs to a large bell which was housed in the Church at Kispiox before that building burned down. It was afterwards taken and used as a school bell but was recently broken. Repairs cost $24. It is now intended to erect a staging from which to suspend the bell close to the school and it is estimated that this will cost $20. On behalf of the Kispiox Natives who own it, Mr. Morris has asked if the Department would bear the cost of repairs and of the staging. Undoubtedly, this bell serves a very useful purpose, for it is large enough to be heard from one end of the Reserve to the other and being rung sometime before school assembly, it serves to arouse parents and children from bed and an hour later summons them to school. I feel that we might reasonably pay these costs or at least a major portion of them.

J.V. Boys,
Indian Agent.

Further to my letter of 10th September I wish to advise that we have erected a new toilet at the teacherage at Kispiox and done some minor painting to the interior.

There is no woodshed on this building and I feel that we may reasonably provide one, size 20' x 14'. For this purpose we would require 1200 f.b.m. rough lumber at $40.00, plus two rolls roofing at $4.95 per roll.

We require a further 500 f.b.m. rough lumber to erect a new toilet at the school for girls plus a roll of roofing at $4.95. This voucher covers materials purchased for repairs to the Kispiox Indian Day School and the Mission House, which is at present being used as a Teacherage. In this connection I would refer you to your letter of September 18th, file 1-11-3, also to Purchase Order No. 17267.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, and in reply to that portion in which you refer to the appointment of a successor to Miss Kilbourne at Kitumant I beg to say that from the 1st instant the Kitumant school will rank as a boarding school and provision has been made to pay the rent for 20 pupils at $100.00 per capita. Dear Sir:

Replying to your of Sept. 23 addressed to the Secretary, Miss Lawson, I beg to say that Miss Lawson was suddenly called home to St. John's, N.B., by her mother's illness and untimely death, and asked me to take charge of her work until some other arrangement was made.

With regard to the reports of recent peculiar that the Dept. should be in the dark about our educational work here. However perhaps we can make it clear now. Permit me then to say that we have two Boarding Schools, both entirely by the Church, and until now maintained entirely by the Church. Also we have a Day School, the building having been built three years ago by the Indian Department of Canada. This school is a separate institution from the Church. The school is a school, i.e., in close union with the Boarding School. There is no school, i.e., in close union with the Boarding School, but the children of the latter attend the day school as do the children from the homes of the village. The Principal of the Boarding School and the Principal of the Day School are two different and independent workers, not necessarily under the same authority. Accordingly the reports are only under the same authority. Accordingly the reports you have are reports of the Day School only, and accordingly you have no report of the Boarding School. I would be glad if you would find time to send a copy to the Dept. as it may help to avoid difficulties in the future.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

I beg to report that this office is in receipt of a letter from Miss Hazel Guild, teacher of day school at Kitimat, dated December 24th, 1930, from which I beg to quote as follows:

"I have 52 pupils enrolled with a promise of four others after vacation. The seating capacity of the room is taxed to its utmost. It seems to me that another department in the school will be a necessity here very shortly - if teacher and pupils are to have a fair chance to do their best."

As the Department will know there is at Kitimat, a residential school for girls of all ages, and for boys up to twelve years of age. The pupils from the residential school receive classroom instruction in buildings detached from the residential school, together with day school pupils from the village, by the same teacher, at present, Miss Hazel Guild.

Fifty-two pupils are too many for one teacher to handle properly, and it would be well if arrangements could be made for an assistant teacher. If the pupils from the residential school could be taught separately from those from the village, the class room would not be crowded.

In your letter of April 6th, 1930, No. 162-16-5, this school was promised a new floor, and I trust this matter will not be forgotten; the old floor is of fir, and slivery.

Obediently yours,

Reverend Sir:

I wish to acquaint you with the situation at the Kitamaat Indian Residential School and at the Day School there. There is a small boarding school, conducted by the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church. As the pupils of this boarding school receive their classroom instruction along with day scholars from the Indian village at the day school, the classroom has become very crowded. The school is not successful. There are far too many children in the school for this teacher to handle. About 75% of the children were at their desks doing nothing. The teacher has no idea of how to handle seat work for the remainder while she teaches one class.

This teacher is resigning her position at the end of the school term.

There is little difficulty in getting the children to come to school. I was very sorry to hear that the present teacher turned away about 8 boys from the village who wished to attend school. Her reason for this was that she had no room with 59 on the roll. In addition there are other children in the village who should be at school.

A second schoolroom is needed at Kitamaat to take care of the increased attendance. If the children from the Residential School did not attend the Day School there would be no need for the extra room. There is no room at the Residential School that could be used as a schoolroom. It has been suggested that the sewing room be used as a schoolroom. This is impossible as it would not accommodate the 36 children, perhaps not more than 12. In any case it is not suitable as a schoolroom. It seems possible that the Residential School may be closed. The children at the Residential School come for the most part from Kitamaat Village. If the Residential School closes we shall have these children in the Day School. The teacher of the Day School is apparently a member of the Staff of the Residential School. I fail to see why the Residential School, while in receipt of per capita grant for the children living there, does not provide for their education at the Residential School.

Owing to the large number of children in attendance at this school a well trained teacher is necessary, one who has special qualifications in Primary Work. I hope that the Department will not sanction the appointment of any but a B.C. trained teacher for the next school year.

With the building of the new Indian day school, providing accommodation for all children of school age, in the village of Kitimat, and the apparent intention of the Department of Indian Affairs to substitute the day school system for the partial residential school system of education now accommodating the Indians of Kitimat, concern is felt by the Kitimat Indian Band and the educational and mission workers among the Kitimat people as to the future of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home.

The Kitimat Band and the Mission workers have greatly appreciated the privileges in education that have been extended to them by the Department of Indian Affairs through the facilities of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home and the Coqualeetza Residential School, and realise that the considerable advance made by the Kitimat Band in economic self-support, in domestic housing and appointments, and in appreciation of morality and right living has been almost entirely due to the training in these institutions.

It is respectfully submitted, however, that, if it is the intention of the Department of Indian Affairs to withdraw support from the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, thus necessitating the closing of that institution, a complete investigation be made of the circumstances of industrial employment of the Kitimat people to determine whether:

1. The seasonal migration of the Kitimat people to provide means of livelihood can be so restricted and controlled as to permit of the attendance of the Kitimat children at the new day school during a reasonable school term without causing serious depletion of the income of the Indian people.

2. If it is found that migration due to seasonal occupations cannot be so restricted, the change from complete residential school facilities, provided heretofore by the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home and the Coqualeetza school, to intermittent, short-period attendance at the new day school is a change of so drastic a nature as to retard the progress of the Kitimat people.

Migrations of the Kitimat Band in search of support-providing occupation in the fishing, canning, logging and trapping industries vary from year to year, depending, to a large extent, on whether the summer fishing and cannery occupation provides sufficient income for the support of families at home on the reserve during at least the earlier part of the winter. If, as the situation particularly was during the 1940 summer fishing and cannery season, sufficient income is not thus derived, then it would seem to be a necessity to family support that the winter occupations of canning, logging and trapping be engaged in, these means of employment having hitherto required the migration of families from the reserve.

Attention should be drawn to the fact that there are no means of income-generating occupation to be found on, or in the immediate vicinity of the Kitimat Reserve.
The function of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home in taking charge of the children of parents who find it necessary to leave the reserve to engage in occupations contributing to means of support, thus ensuring the full school term education of the children, has been one of increasing necessity of recent years. During the school term beginning September 1st 1940 to the end of January 1941 the approximate average attendance of pupils at the present day school was 50. Of these, 40 were domiciled in the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home during the absence of their parents engaged in support-providing occupation away from the reserve. During this period, therefore, were it not for the services of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, out of a total of some 70 children of school age belonging to the Kitimat reserve, the day school attendance would have been approximately 10.

While the income from the summer fishing of 1940 was perhaps unusually poor, necessitating possibly a greater fall and winter migration than is sometimes necessary, there is, nevertheless, no indication that the summer fishing in succeeding years will provide an appreciably greater income than that of 1940, keeping in mind that one of the prime causes of the depletion of Indian income from this source is the large number of fishermen engaged in the industry on the coasts of British Columbia, there being no prospect of a change for the better in this situation.

The following sets forth the seasonal movements of the large majority of the Kitimat people during the year, March 1st 1940 to Feb. 26th, 1941, the dates given being approximate:

March 1st - April 1st...Commercial fishing and canning workers at home at Kitimat.
Trapping workers engaged until March 15th.
Logging workers engaged during month.

April 1st - May 15th...Entire population engaged in codlachan fishing and the rendering of codlachan oil, also smoking and drying fish and the planting of potatoes at the Old Reserve, distant about 4 miles from Kitimat.

May 15th - June 10th...All at Kitimat.

June 10th - August 15th...Part of population fishing and canning at River's Inlet.

June 10th - Sept. 15th...Rest of population fishing and canning Bute Dale, Gardner Canal or Skeena River.

Aug. 15th - Sept. 15th...River's Inlet workers home at Kitimat.

Sept. 15th - Feb. 1st...Part population having canning at Bute Dale. (women mainly employed)

Sept. 15th - March 1st...Rest of population mainly engaged in trapping and logging.

Feb. 1st - March 1st...Bute Dale workers expected to return to Kitimat.

It should also be noted that while the Indian men are engaged at the logging and trapping camps, the women are occupied at these camps cooking, providing native foods and bottling and smoking meats.

Should the suggested investigation corroborate the foregoing facts, it is requested that the Department of Indian Affairs continue to support the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home in the interests of the uninterrupted continuance of the primary education of the children of the Kitimat Band, at least until such time as it may be definitely determined that a restriction of customary migration, permitting care of the children in the Indian homes and their attendance at the day school during a reasonable school term, can be resorted to without reducing the Indian income below a point necessary for home and child support.

Dear Mr. Christie,

I am enclosing herewith marriage certificates.

I am sorry that you could not have come up here as there are a number of things I would like to discuss with you. Perhaps it is just as well you did not come for, with the Supt. of Missions aboard, and only staying here for a short time there would not have been much opportunity for you to be done.

Most of the people are back on the Reserve again, still at the reduction plant at Butedale, some trapping and logging. I think the opportunity is good to institute the election in the Council that you intended last fall, and it is a question much needed. A proper organization, with an elected council, would, I am sure, do much to regulate matters on this reserve. It would also be of great advantage to the restriction of migration of the people, thus enabling the children to attend the new day school at least during the winter months.

I am strongly of the opinion, for several reasons, that Butedale migration during the winter should be definitely discouraged. First, such migration is an economic loss to the Reserve. With the absence from the Reserve of the population of last year, the average cash receipts for wages by the women was about $15.00. The men will average less as few of them are employed. Much more could have been made by trapping and logging, as is admitted by the people themselves. Some of the people were trapping before they left for Butedale, and admitted that they were very well at trapping. The urge to leave the reserve is simply the old idea of congregating together, especially when there is opportunity of license. Speaking from the point of view of administration, the reports of homebrewing and gambling at Butedale, indulged in by both the women and the men, cannot be anything but a bad effect, particularly on the younger people who are permitted more license generally at the fishing camps.

This behaviour is not evident when the people are at home in Kitimat. With a strong Council and Chief the whole situation can be controlled.
I would strongly recommend that the financing of logging equipment be arranged for the Kitimat people as it was for Bella Coola. It is true that past experience does not appear to warrant this step, but there was a conspicuous lack of organization and of authoritative Council supervision during these past operations and also there was the complication of the use of private equipment. I think that the people are ready for a reorganization of the Council and I have (in conversation) suggested that, if the people of Kitimat would lay out a definite working policy, acceptable to the Department, in a logging operation, it might be possible to get the assistance required.

Further, there is the matter of the restriction of migration from the Reserve (at least by the women) so that the children can attend the new day school. We have gone into this recently and it is a matter that should be thoroughly investigated. I see no reason why the women cannot remain home during the school term, but there must be definite restrictions placed upon them. The encouraging of the logging industry will assist in removing some of the excuse for migration. Certainly, the migration to Butedale this winter was not an economic advantage. It should be a matter of concern to the Department that, had it not been for the care of some 40 children in the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home during this school term beginning September 1st, the attendance at the day school would have averaged about 9 out of some 70 children of school age in the Band.

According to the Indian Act, the Life Chief can retain his title during his lifetime, if the system is changed to an elective one. However, the elective chief would have the authority. Definite by-laws could and should be made on this Reserve giving the Council such control of Reserve conduct as is permitted by the Department. It should also be pointed out to the Council, in the event of the new system being established, that, in enforcing their by-laws, the Council cannot constitute itself a Court, but must look to the Indian agent or other appointed judicial authority for the levying of penalties. This is a procedure that is not at present understood by the Band.

I may say that a reorganization as suggested would meet with the approval of at least two-thirds of the Band, especially the younger generation. As an instance of this, the prospective life chief, Gordon Robinson, whose marriage certificate I enclose, states that he is not in favour of the continuance of the life chief system. Gordon's recent experience has been very trying. As the prospective chief, his family, and the old "aristocracy" of the Band, insisted on picking his wife for him. He became engaged to another girl, and, as the family did everything they could to separate them, Gordon took the course (practically forced by circumstances into it) of co-habiting with the girl he wanted to
forestall any attempt to separate them. I married them, but without the consent of Gordon's family. A new system would do away with the old idea that the elders have the privilege of arranging the marriage of the young people without their consent. The present system has much to do with the marriage complications now prevalent and is no incentive to morality.

I think it would be to the advantage of the Kitimat people if these matters were gone into by Department authority. The younger and more progressive people cannot buck the old system successfully unless they have the strong backing of authority.

I will have to get another couple of cords of wood in a day or two for the day-school. As this is necessary, I presume it will be sanctioned if you do not come up in the meantime. The wood that was originally put up was green and iced from being stacked outdoors and it has been a constant job to keep the fire going. However, the school is in good condition. I will have to leave the firing with the chief when I leave, and some arrangements will have to be made with him.

I have your letter re the potato club. I think, perhaps, this had better wait until you come up. Under the present circumstances, where there is no attention given to the gardens in the summer, I don't think much could be done with a Club here. I do not, however, see any necessity for the supply of seed potatoes here yearly. The people should be instructed that the supply of seed is not now necessary, that they should pit their seed in a community pit, or keep them in their cellars during the winter. If they knew there was no prospect of obtaining further seed they would take care to keep seed out of the crop. As you know, the reserve is completely deserted from June until about the end of August, and thus the crop gets no summer care.

I am busy packing and will leave on next boat. I must be in Winnipeg on March 15th to take plane for Norway House. I hope you will be able to get up before I leave so that we can talk things over. I may say that a request has gone in to the Church, which will doubtless reach the Department for an investigation of the conditions surrounding the industrial migration of the Kitimat people before the Department withdraws support from the School Home. As I have said, I do not see any need for the migration to Butedale during the winter. Dear Mr. Christie,

I am enclosing herewith marriage certificate for registration.

I am sorry that you could not have come up on the "Crosby" as there are a number of things I would like to talk over with you. Perhaps it is just as well you did not come for, with the Doctor and Supt. of Missions aboard, and only staying here one evening, there would not have been much opportunity for you to get much done.

Most of the people are back on the Reserve again, some being still at the reduction plant at Butedale, some trapping and some logging. I think the opportunity is good to institute the change in the Council that you intended last fall, and it is a reorganization much needed. A proper organization, with an elected chief, would, I am sure, do much to regulate matters on this reserve, and would also be of great advantage to the restriction of unnecessary migration of the people, thus enabling the children to attend the new day school at least during the winter months.

I am strongly of the opinion, for several reasons, that the Butedale migration during the winter should be definitely discouraged. First, such migration is an economic loss to the reserve. With the absence from the reserve of the population since October last, the average cash receipts for wages by the women has been about $15.00. The men will average less as few of them were employed. Much more could have been made by trapping and logging. This is admitted by the people themselves. Some of the men had been trapping before they left for Butedale, and admittedly had done very well at trapping. The urge to leave the reserve for Butedale is simply the old idea of congregating together, especially where there is opportunity of license. Speaking from the sole point of view of administration, the reports of homebrewing and drinking at Butedale, indulged in by both the women and the men, cannot have anything but a bad effect, particularly on the younger people, who are permitted more license generally at the fishing camp.

This behaviour is not evident when the people are at home at Kitimat. With a strong Council and Chief the whole situation could be controlled.
I would strongly recommend that the financing of logging equipment be arranged for the Kitimat people as it was for Bella Coola. It is true that past experience does not appear to warrant this step, but there was a conspicuous lack of organization and of authoritative Council supervision during these past operations and also there was the complication of the use of private equipment. I think that the people are ready for a reorganization of the Council and I have (in conversation) suggested that, if the people of Kitimat would lay out a definite working policy, acceptable to the Department, in a logging operation, it might be possible to get the assistance required.

Further, there is the matter of the restriction of migration from the Reserve (at least by the women) so that the children can attend the new day school. We have gone into this recently and it is a matter that should be thoroughly investigated. I see no reason why the women cannot remain home during the school term, but there must be definite restrictions placed upon them. The encouraging of the logging industry will assist in removing some of the excuse for migration. Certainly, the migration to Butedale this winter was not an economic advantage. It should be a matter of concern to the Department that, had it not been for the care of some 40 children in the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home during this school term beginning September 1st, the attendance at the day school would have averaged about 9 out of some 70 children of school age in the Band.

According to the Indian Act, the Life Chief can retain his title during his lifetime, if the system is changed to an elective one. However, the elective chief would have the authority. Definite by-laws could and should be made on this Reserve giving the Council such control of reserve conduct as is permitted by the Department. It should also be pointed out to the Council, in the event of the new system being established, that, in enforcing their by-laws, the Council cannot constitute itself a Court, but must look to the Indian agent or other appointed judicial authority for the levying of penalties. This is a procedure that is not at present understood by the Band.

I may say that a reorganization as suggested would meet with the approval of at least two-thirds of the Band, especially the younger generation. As an instance of this, the prospective life chief, Gordon Robinson, whose marriage certificate I enclose, states that he is not in favour of the continuance of the life chief system. Gordon's recent experience has been very trying. As the prospective chief, his family, and the old "aristocracy" of the Band, insisted on picking his wife for him. He became engaged to another girl, and, as the family did everything they could to separate them, Gordon took the course (practically forced by circumstances into it) of co-habiting with the girl he wanted to
forestall any attempt to separate them. I married them, but without the consent of Gordon's family. A new system would do away with the old idea that the elders have the privilege of arranging the marriage of the young people without their consent. The present system has much to do with the marriage complications now prevalent and is no incentive to morality.

I think it would be to the advantage of the Kitimat people if these matters were gone into by Department authority. The younger and more progressive people cannot buck the old system successfully unless they have the strong backing of authority.

I will have to get another couple of cords of wood in a day or two for the day-school. As this is necessary, I presume it will be sanctioned if you do not come up in the meantime. The wood that was originally put up was green and iced from being stacked outdoors and it has been a constant job to keep the fire going. However, the school is in good condition. I will have to leave the firing with the chief when I leave, and some arrangements will have to be made with him.

I have your letter re the potato club. I think, perhaps, this had better wait until you come up. Under the present circumstances, where there is no attention given to the gardens in the summer, I don't think much could be done with a Club here. I do not, however, see any necessity for the supply of seed potatoes here yearly. The people should be instructed that the supply of seed is not now necessary, that they should pit their seed in a community pit, or keep them in their cellars during the winter. If they knew there was no prospect of obtaining further seed they would take care to keep seed out of the crop, as you know, the reserve is completely deserted from June until about the end of August, and thus the crop gets no summer care.

I am busy packing and will leave on next boat. I must be in Winnipeg on March 15th to take plane for Norway House. I hope you will be able to get up before I leave so that we can talk things over. I may say that a request has gone in to the Church, which will doubtless reach the Department for an investigation of the conditions surrounding the industrial migration of the Kitimat people before the Department withdraws support from the School Home. Personally, I do not see how any appreciable attendance can be expected at the day school under the present conditions without the services of the Home. In the course of a year or so, it might be arranged that the women stay home from the trapping and logging camps so that the children can go to school. As I have said, I do not see any need for the migration to Buteaud during the winter. However, this will have to be arranged by the exertion of authority by the Department, unless there is a reorganization of the Council as I have suggested, in which case the Council will have the function of regulating the movements of the people so...
that the children can attend school.

It does not appear that a successor to myself will be appointed here until Conference time in May. In the meantime it is arranged that the teacher, Miss Horton, takes a service on Sunday. To do this it has been arranged that she be relieved from all her duties in the Home. Probably Mrs. Durnin will be given another staff member. Miss Field is taking over the Post Office pro-tem.

If you could come up on the Steamer to Butedale I think it would not be difficult to get a boat to bring you here and take you back. I believe Donald Grant is now at Butedale awaiting repairs to his engine so that he can come here. Once here you could get a boat to go back to Butedale. Whether the circumstances would warrant the expense involved you know best. You perhaps would find it necessary to make a report on the new school, the additional work to be done on the surroundings, and also the question of whether it should be opened before next fall. The present school is quite full now, but there will be the departure for the Old Reserve for Colachan fishing soon and the school will again have few, if any, children from the village attending.

I think that is about all I have to report for the present.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

"A.E.Caldwell"
Dear Sir:

Your file 15/2/1743.

I beg to acknowledge your letter of April 20, 1941, enclosing memo from Mr. A. L. Caldwell regarding the closing of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home.

There is no doubt that considerable difficulty will be experienced for a year or two before a satisfactory attendance can be obtained for the new Day School at Kitimat. The Indians have become so long accustomed to the Department looking after their children of school age, feeding and clothing them, and thus relieving them of considerable expense.

The Elizabeth Long Memorial Home has been in some ways a success for the pupils fortunate enough to be admitted. On the other hand the children who were not admitted, perhaps on medical grounds or for some other reason, have been very badly discriminated against, since the teacher and school which was rightly theirs, has been used by the Residential School pupils, who have always had a certain amount of preference. This has resulted in the disorganized state of affairs now so apparent when these children have reached manhood and womanhood, laying the foundations of different factions which have become organized into clubs. The result is that with all the advantages these children have received, educated at the Home, a large number at Coqualeetza, they are now unable to earn their own village utilities and have been involved as a community to the extent of at least $1,000.00, which they have been urged by the Agent several occasions to make some attempt to pay off and retain their good name as a whole. This statement I am making does not exactly confirm the second paragraph of Mr. Caldwell's memorandum.

The occupations which these Indians follow during the school year and as listed by Mr. Caldwell, are Logging, Trapping, Herring Canning, Oolachan fishing, and working at the Reduction Plant at Butedale. These industries will be considered in order as follows:

1. TRAPPING:- Most of the Kitimat Indians have traplines but, it should be also pointed out, that all the other Bands in this Agency are trapping during the winter months and are becoming more and more in the habit of leaving their women folk and children at home during the trapping season. As a matter of opinion I see no earthly excuse for the women and school children going on the trap lines, and it should be noted that the Ulkatcho Band who are considered one of the most backward tribes in B. C. and whose women folk have been accustomed to taking an active part, managed to arrange to leave their children at home during the school term.

2. LOGGING:- Had I received your letter in time I would have been able to give you a more accurate report on the number of school children affected by the logging operations.
Last year several of the Indians worked for Lee and Simberg and Frank Hallett. The earnings at Lee and Simberg amounted to approximately $3,600.00 of which $1,164.00 was earned by Lloyd Starr. He is a single man without any children. The earnings at Hallett's camp was around $2,000.00. Possibly 12 school children would be affected by this work and here again it is difficult to see why the women can not remain at home and take care of the children.

3. COLACHAN FISHING
A.D. Gardiner:— Colachan fishing is carried on at the mouth of the Kitimat River about three miles from the village and usually lasts about two weeks during April. The gardens are situated at the old village close to the Colachan grounds. None of these occupations in my opinion constitute a valid reason why the children cannot attend school. As you suggest transportation by gas boat can easily be arranged or they can also arrange for their care at home. It might also be suggested that holidays are curtailed at Christmas by one week and at Easter and two weeks taken during this time.

4. BERRING CANNING AND FORK LADY REDUCTION PLANT AT BUTE ISLE:—
This is a new occupation at Butedale cannery during the winter months and I would direct your attention to copy of a report on Kitimat matters received from Mr. Caldwell before he left. It will be noted that the earnings from this source last winter were very small and that mostly women were employed. The living quarters for the Indians at Butedale are deplorable (at least during the winter months and the Provincial Health authorities should be asked to investigate.) In the interests of health and morality the Canneries should be asked to employ only women without children during the winter and provide a central bunkhouse for these women with a responsible matron in charge. Should the Indian Department interfere, they will probably inform them that there is plenty of Chinese and Japanese help available.

The Kitimat Band are in a similar position to the Bella Coola Band, with the exception that the Bella Coola's are not employed at the Cannery during the winter months and are developing a local logging industry.

It is unfortunate that the Kitimat Village is located on its present site. There is no good reason for the present location as there is a very poor harbour and they are also three miles distant from their gardens and a considerable acreage of Agricultural land. This makes it difficult to develop any local industry.

In conclusion I would say that providing the Kitimat people have a true appreciation of the educational facilities provided for them by the Department, which they should have since a very large proportion are literate and have attended the Bone and Coqualeetza Schools, there should be no difficulty.

As Mr. Caldwell remarks most of these migrations during the winter months are simply an excuse to have a good time and the economic side is of secondary importance. Frankly I expect the attendance at the new Day School during the 1941-42 School term to be disappointing and I do not expect the Indians to be at all co-operative. That they should be encouraged in this attitude is another matter but personally I believe that nothing will eventually be gained by too much pampering and that the worthwhile Indians will make some sacrifice to ensure their
children's education. Much also depends, of course, on the quality of the teachers and their ability to make village as well as school life interesting. A married couple who are both teachers and have no children, or a married missionary teacher and a woman for the primary grades is preferable.

Your obedient servant,

Th. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Major J. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to enclose copies of two letters which have come to my desk through the office of the Woman's Missionary Society and which are of some interest. You will note that Major MacKay is asking the Woman's Missionary Society to nominate to him various teachers. The letters were addressed to "Rev. J. S. Mildrew," but I would gather that this is merely an error, as Mr. Mildrew's wife is the President of the Woman's Missionary Society in British Columbia.

Whilst I have the highest regard for Major MacKay and his efficiency, I am writing to ask if your Department has inaugurated a new system of dealing with the appointment of teachers to Indian schools in British Columbia, - and particularly in relation to the Woman's Missionary Society. My understanding of the relations which we have with your Department is that all United Church appointments and nominations come through this office; and, even if you had decided to have nominations in British Columbia made through the Commissioner, my understanding would be that, instead of splitting the matter up into fragments and having the local branch of the Woman's Missionary Society handle their affairs, nominations should still come through the office here. I hope that this can be straightened up satisfactorily. I do not think that Major MacKay should write to Mrs. Mildrew or to any of the local officers. The Woman's Missionary Society is a national body and its offices are in Toronto. If your Department feels that it must correspond with the Woman's Missionary Society in connection with Indian matters, may I say that the name of the Executive Secretary is Mrs. C. M. Lovews, and her office is in this Building.

May I say that I wrote to Mr. Hunt, suggesting that it would be useful if he would from time to time, let in touch with Major MacKay, so that, if it were thought advisable to change teachers from one school to another, the Commissioner might have the opportunity of making suggestions. We have appreciated the co-operation of Major MacKay in the past, and we rather think that what has occurred is an error for which someone, who is not familiar with the methods laid down to be followed by your Department, is responsible.
I should be glad to take up with the Woman's Missionary Society the question of nominations for the Kitimat Indian Day School, if it is desired to continue the present arrangement.

With regard to Major MacKay's letter concerning Mr. Glover: It has been customary for nominations to be made to your Department. This was done last year and Mr. Glover was nominated. I realize, of course, that all appointments are yearly, but it has been the custom of your Department to write us very definitely from time to time concerning teachers whose work was unsatisfactory, saying that you were notifying the teacher in question that his or her services were no longer required and asking either our Board or the Woman's Missionary Society to nominate a successor. So far as I know, Mr. Glover has not been notified by your Department that his services are not satisfactory. Certainly, nothing has come to this office or to that of the Woman's Missionary Society. I know that there has not been the greatest satisfaction concerning Mr. Glover, but that is altogether different from official intimation to Mr. Glover that his services were no longer required by the Department and notice to the Woman's Missionary Society through this Office that a new nomination was asked for. I think, under the circumstances, that Mr. Glover should be continued as teacher for another year, unless, of course, his services are so very unsatisfactory that you cannot continue him. Further, if this is the case, may I say we shall expect compensation for the fact that Mr. Glover was not notified sooner.

Dear Sir:

While you have possibly received it, I thought it advisable to forward to you a copy of Indian Agent Christie's report on the Kitimat School included in his report on the Bella Coola Agency for the month of February.

It is disappointing to see such a small attendance at this school but I presume that it is due to circumstances over which we have no control. It is quite possible that due to the changed conditions regarding fishing and other causes there may be considerable shifting of the population of the reserves on the coast for the duration of the war. Under these circumstances it would be appreciated if Inspector Barry could give the matter some consideration, with a view to making a definite recommendation to the Department regarding the policy which we should follow at day schools on the coast during the academic year 1942-43.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
At Kitimat very few of the Band were at home with only 21 pupils attending the Day School out of a possible attendance of nearly 30. The teachers, none of whom have taught Indian children before, seem rather dissatisfied although they made no specific complaint. The discipline seemed none too good in the junior room although the children were clean and happy. The Senior room was under good control although only eight pupils were present.

Air Raid Drill has been carried out in addition to Fire Drill. This matter was taken up with the parents who agreed that the children should take to the bush behind the school, the younger children in charge of the older ones. Although there was a small attendance a test was made and all the children were out of sight in the timber within three minutes of the signal.

Miss Faust complains of lack of work, which is rather unusual. She is quite willing to go to Butedale Cannery or Kitasu Reserve however, should the Department consider this to be necessary and a report and recommendation has gone forward to the Indian Commissioner.

Some friction seems apparent between the Missionary or his wife, Mrs. Hartley, and the teachers, one of the sore points being that the teachers have got the piano which belonged to the Residential School.

WM. Christie,
Indian Agent.
