Dear Sir:

We are at present at Kitamaat awaiting the arrival of the Union Boat from Vancouver. She should have been here yesterday evening, but has evidently gone to Prince Rupert first, and is calling here on her south bound trip.

On arrival here found the Field Matron sick in bed, and Miss Vermilyea, has not been teaching since the 31st of the month. She is also sick, and I would say both physically and mentally, and I would say that the sooner she gets out of here the better for all concerned.

She is broke, has not the price of her fare out of here, and as I have not sufficient funds to pay her fare, I am issuing a Transport Warrant to Vancouver. Will there be any chance to stop her cheque at Vancouver, or at Ottawa, and have the amount of her fare deducted from it?

I am not sure what the fare is, but they tell me that they paid $16.40 from Vancouver here, and I expect that will be the same for the return.

There are only about 20 pupils attending the school, so it will be just as well that she leaves, as there is not enough work here for two teachers.

Mrs Waywell seems to be a very efficient teacher, and has the best control in the class room that I have seen in any of the Indian Schools in this Agency.

Have commenced work on wood shed, ground is all leveled out and a lot of the material all ready cut, and am just waiting to see if the shingles, cement and nails are arriving on the boat. It is now in sight and should be here in about twenty minutes.

It seems that there will be very few people at the village during the winter, as a large number of them are going to Butedale to work, and naturally they are taking their families with them, so that the attendance here will be very light.

Saw the Manager at Butedale on north bound, but as the regular manager is off on holidays, nothing definite was arrived at, in regards to the possibility of getting a school at Butedale. I promised to get in touch with the head office in Vancouver, but thought that with the shortage of lumber etc., there was only a slight chance of getting anything going this winter. Will however see him on my south bound trip, and he may have something from the head office. Boat whistled for the dock so will have to close.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir:

On a recent visit to Kitamaat, I found the Teacher of the Junior room, Kitamaat Indian Day School, sick, and she had not been teaching for some little time.

She commenced teaching on Monday, Sept. 21st, and taught to Oct. 21st, a total of twenty-two teaching days.

She had already sent in her resignation to the W.M.S., which was the logical thing to do, as her health would not permit her staying on at Kitamaat, and as there were so few children attending school, owing to the parents having moved to Buteale Cannery for the winter.

The unfortunate part was that she was financially up against it, and had not the price of her fare back to Vancouver, and as the other white workers there were pretty much in the same condition, I finally had to issue a transportation warrant for her from Kitamaat to Vancouver, on the understanding that this would have to be repaid out of her salary cheque, when received.

I would strongly recommend that in the future, the churches nominating anyone for positions in these outlying schools, should be asked to have nominees have a physical examination before they are sent out, as I can recollect several instances where teachers have had to be sent out after just a few weeks work, and as in this case, a lot of them are not in a position to pay their transportation back again.

Yours Truly,

T.A. Levelton

Dear Mrs. Waywell:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 24, in which you seek information with respect to employees of the Government who have joined or may join the Armed Forces of Canada.

It is somewhat difficult to explain the laws and regulations governing this matter. However, I shall make an attempt. If the information in this letter is not satisfactory, I want you to feel free to communicate with me again.

Permanent Civil Servants, who are classified as such and who join the Armed Forces, are given leave of absence without pay and certain considerations in respect to superannuation payments. They are given full assurance that their positions will be restored to them immediately following their discharge from the Army. Temporary Civil Servants, who were appointed to permanent positions but whose length of service prior to the outbreak of the war did not enable them to attain the full status of permanent Civil Servants, are also given an assurance that either the position they occupied at the time of enlistment or an equivalent position will be given them at the time of their discharge.

In addition to this all men who have served in the Armed Forces overseas or, as it is usually interpreted, in an actual theatre of war, are given a preference when applying for positions in the Civil Service. Returned soldiers have enjoyed this statutory preference since the close of the last war.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

On the following day left for Butedale, and filled up with gas and water but was unable to get any provisions until after the arrival of the Steamer the following day, and as this was Sunday the store was not opened, so had to wait till Monday morning, and as the weather was good we went up to Kitamaat, arriving there about 5.30 P.M.

On the following day visited the School, and found 18 pupils present, and as there were a number of families returning from Butedale that day, it is possible that class room would be filled to capacity. Light plant was not working satisfactorily, but think it was due to a faulty spark plug, as it would run but irregularly missing quite often. Sent in two new spark plugs from Bella Bella on my return trip. The field matron told me she would be leaving in March, but did not say whether she would stay the month out or not.

There seemed to be some friction between the Missionary, and his wife on the one side and the Teacher and the Field Matron on the other, but as I understand the Missionary and his wife are leaving in the summer, it is to be hoped that the Teacher will decide to stay for another term.

Left at about 6 p.m. and went to Lee & Genberg's camp, saw Lee in regards to right of way across the fish Indian Reserve, and then left for Butedale, where we looked over the building which it was proposed to turn into a school room for the coming winter.

We left Kitamaat at about 4.15 and arrived back at Buteadale at 11.40 P.M.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1944.

Schools:

Schools;

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1943.

Schools:

Day schools at Bella Coola, Klemtu, Bella Bella (2 division) and the empty schoolhouse at Kitamaat were all carefully inspected. Attendance is not satisfactory at all; Klemtu and Bella Coola have most unsuitable persons as teachers; and the closing of the latter school has been recommended. I am afraid that the School at Bella Bella will suffer a serious attendance lapse. War services take men and women in a wholesale manner from the villages winter as well as summer, and if the war goes on much longer, the entire social economy of these Indians will require serious review. In the old days there were at least six months in which the parents would be home; today in some villages, they are home for two weeks at Xmas or for a wedding or funeral; and children by the score are not attending school at all. It is very moot point in my opinion, as to whether home life in Indian villages will ever return to its former status, and I foresee the possibility of "ghost Villages" not long hence. Just where Councils will fit in to the picture of the future is a baffling problem, and future objectives along these lines will need careful study.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BELLA COOLA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Schools; Day.

All schools in operation were visited and inspected. It is a shame that no teachers are available for Kitamaat and Bella Coola. Attendance at Bella Bella is fairly good, but I am afraid that after the new year, it will take a slump as many of these people are due to go to Namu Cannery for work. The school at Bella Coola is overcrowded. Repairs have been done at Klemtu and the building at least looks clean inside. It will last until better days come and a proper unit can be put up, with teachers quarters attached. It is suggested that at Kitamaat a local Indian with Grade XI standing be appointed interim teacher, to get one room going at least. He seems a fine kind of young man, and he could not be any worse than some white interim or temporary appointments at present in action.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Education: During the past quarter the senior teacher at Bella Bella resigned and has been replaced. It has not been possible to secure a second teacher for Bella Coola. A new school has been established at Upper Dean River at Anahim Lake, but so far no appointment has been made. A second teacher was secured for the Kitamaat school. Attendance on the whole has improved but education in the broader sense of the word is the real weak link in the Indian programme. Right now in B.C., there is no inspector of Indian Schools, qualifications for teaching and calibre of appointments made is generally very low and most schools are seriously overcrowded. These conditions are not conducive of a good response by the pupils and a complete overhauling of the entire educational policy of the Department appears more and more urgent as time goes on. There is a great deal of criticism by the parents of the operation of the Residential Schools and some of this is undoubtedly based on real grievances, caused by unsuitable staffing of the schools in question.

F. Earl Ashfield,
Indian Agent.

Re: Kitamaat Indian Day School

The above school was opened on September 26th. There were only five pupils in the village and Mrs. Morrison, who arrived in Kitamaat on Saturday September 16th, opened the school for these pupils.

Mr. Robinson had been waiting in Kitamaat from September 10th for the people to arrive home. He had been busy doing small repairs around the school house and his own home. As there still remained some work of that type to be done when I visited Kitamaat on September 26th I advised Mr. Robinson to continue this work for a few days until a reasonable number of pupils arrived in the village to open the second room.

I recommend that Mrs. J. M. Morrison be paid commencing September 26th and that Mr. G. W. Robinson be paid commencing September 10th. As cheque for the latter has probably already gone forward, adjustment of the three days missing from September 7th when school should have opened will be expected on a later cheque. I have advised Mr. Robinson accordingly.

Enclosure.

Madam,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to the cheque forwarded you in payment of the salary of the teacher of the Kitamat Indian Day School for the September quarter.

The Department has recently decided to pay the salaries of Indian day school teachers on the basis of ten teaching months in the school year. In this connection I enclose herewith a copy of circular letter of September 15th, last, which was forwarded to our Indian agents and teachers of Indian day schools.

With reference to the Kitamat Day School, the amount allowed for September quarter, 1923, is one-tenth of the yearly salary, or, $60.00; and at the end of each of the other three quarters $180.00 will be paid.

For the school year, therefore, beginning with the September quarter and ending with the June quarter the full amount of salary allowed will be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Kitimat Indian Day School
No. 820

The Department has appointed Mr. Gordon Robinson as teacher of this school, effective December 5, 1944, at a salary of $100 a teaching month. I enclose T.D. 1 form, cost-of-living bonus form and copy of letter of appointment. Staff questionnaire will be forwarded to you in the near future.

Unless further advised by this Branch, Mr. Robinson should be paid from December 5, 1944, to June 30, 1945.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, January 9, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

On the nomination of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, the Department has approved the appointment of Mrs. Ann W. Evans as teacher of the Kitamaat Indian Day School.

It should be definitely understood by all parties concerned that Mrs. Evans is to be considered the senior teacher of this school and Mr. Robinson as the assistant. You were advised of Mr. Robinson's appointment in official letter of November 23, 1944.

Mrs. Evans has had teaching experience in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Ontario. She also served on the staff of the Coqualeetza Residential School. We are informed that if, later on, Mrs. Evans finds that she can handle the whole school, you are of the opinion that Mr. Robinson's services might be discontinued. If this is your recommendation, we will expect to hear from you whenever you consider such action timely. We are further advised that Mrs. Evans is the wife of Mr. A.H.J. Evans, who is the author of a couple of novels and who also writes for magazines. Mr. Evans intends to accompany his wife to Kitamaat.

I enclose the usual forms, which you should have Mrs. Evans complete and return at the earliest possible date.

Encl.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, January 9, 1945.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, the Department approves the appointment of Mrs. Ann W. Evans as teacher of the Kitamaat Indian Day School at a salary of $100.00 a month, plus bonus. I note that it is your wish to have Mrs. Evans considered as principal of this school, and our officials will be informed accordingly.

At the time of Mr. Robinson's appointment, we were not aware that you intended appointing a second teacher. Consequently, we informed our officials that he would be allowed salary of $100.00 a month. No doubt, they have already advised him, and under the circumstances I feel that we should let his salary stand at that rate.

Yours sincerely,

for Deputy Minister.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing a requisition for school material from the teacher of the Kitamaat Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that an order is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the supply of classroom material considered necessary.

Relative to the single desks asked for, it is noted that some of the desks at present in use in the school are in a dilapidated condition and that the teacher asks that 12 desks of various sizes and 2 rear seats be supplied. Full particulars should be forwarded regarding the type of desk at present in use at this school. It should also be stated whether they are double or single desks and the name of the manufacturer should, if possible, be given, as it will be necessary in ordering new desks that they be of the same type in order to have uniformity in the seating arrangement. Full shipping directions should also be given. When we have full particulars as requested, consideration will then be given to placing the order for the supplying of the desks from here or authorizing you to do so.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith vouchers No. 15/70 for £50.10 in favor of the Canadian Fishing Co. Ltd., Butedale, B.C.

As to this purchase I beg to explain, as follows:

When I visited Kitimat during the early part of this month, the teacher of the day school, Miss Dimmick informed me that the lining of the stove was burned out, making it unsafe. It was also too small to heat the room properly during cold weather, and the children had not been comfortable.

I examined the stove, and decided that a new one was needed immediately. Hence I ordered a new stove at Butedale cannery. There is only one store at this place, the nearest to Kitimat.

Trusting that my action will be approved, and the vouchers honored.

The Secretary, Dept' of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Obediently yours,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of 14th instant, I beg to say that I am asking for quotation of prices for the articles mentioned.

As to the last sentence of the letter:

"It is understood that the painting will be performed without expense to the Department", I can say that the painting of this comparatively large school-room (inside) is quite an undertaking; and as the teacher is an elderly lady, I do not like to ask her to do it, however willing she may be. I know that the Indians ought to be willing to help with such work, free of charge, but we cannot depend on that. I should like to get permission to pay for the work, if it cannot be done free. The work will likely be done during the next fiscal year.

Obediently yours,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, January 27, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to acquaint you with the situation at the Kitamaat Indian Residential School and at the Day School there. There is a small boarding school, conducted by the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church. As the pupils of this boarding school receive their classroom instruction along with day scholars from the Indian village at the day school, the classroom has become very crowded. There are 52 enrolled at the present time and there will shortly be an additional four. I believe that the privilege granted to the pupils of the boarding school will have to be discontinued, and I have to request that the boarding school management provide a classroom and teacher in residence. The usual residential school per capita grant is paid at Kitamaat, and this should include all teaching services. Will you please, therefore, ask the W. M. S. to arrange, at their earliest convenience, for a separate classroom for the boarding school pupils and for a separate teacher. This will leave the day school building for the day pupils and the Department will continue meeting the expense of this separate activity.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Kenneth J. Beaton, B. A.,
Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,

Ottawa, January 27, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to a communication which you received from the teacher of the Kitimat Indian Day School, in which she states the seating capacity of the classroom is taxed to its utmost. In this connection I have to say that the Department is talking up with the authorities of the United Church of Canada, under whose auspices the residential school at this point is conducted, the question of their arranging to provide classroom accommodation and a teacher for the pupils of the residential school, separate from the present day school. If this is done, there would, no doubt, be ample accommodation at the day school for the pupils who would attend as day scholars. When the Department is informed as to the arrangements the church authorities can provide for classroom accommodation for the pupils of the residential school, you will be advised.

With reference to the installing of a new floor in the day school building, for which you submitted a detailed estimate of the materials and labour in your letter dated April 17th, 1930, I have to say that, no doubt, funds will be available for this improvement next spring. I would request that you again draw the matter to the attention of the Department at that time. It would be advisable that you give a new estimate, stating in detail the costs of the material, labour, etc. If the work is authorized, it could be carried out during the summer holiday period. It is further noted that a shed is required, in which to store the fuel. You might, at the same time, give particulars as to the size and type of shed you would recommend be erected and the cost of the material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, May 23rd, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kitamaat Indian Day School, states that the schoolroom needs a new floor. He does not consider an expensive hardwood floor is required, but states that a floor of edge grain fir would be suitable or even one of ordinary flooring. He further states that there are no toilets, and he recommends that two new toilets be provided previous to the opening of the school for next year. A small woodshed is also required. There is no water in the school and, at very little cost, the pipe that passes the school could be tapped and a pipe run the necessary 20' or so to the school.

Our funds this year are extremely limited and only the absolutely necessary repairs can be authorized at any of our schools. I would, however, request that you furnish a report regarding the above mentioned work. You should state the amount of the above work you consider to be absolutely necessary this year and give, in detail, the work required and the approximate cost of same. When we have full information as to the cost involved in the reflooring of the schoolroom, erection of toilets and woodshed, and extension of the water pipe to the school, consideration will then be given as to what portion of the work, if any, can be authorized this year.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

I. Fougner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.
The 20 double desks should be replaced as soon as possible by 40 single desks. There would, however, be no room for the single desks till such time as a second school-room is provided.

The schoolroom needs a new floor. I understand that a hard wood floor has been asked for. I do not consider that the school needs an expensive hard wood floor. One of edge grain fir would be quite suitable or even one of ordinary flooring.

There are no toilets. I would recommend that two toilets be provided previous to the opening of school for the next year. A small woodshed is also required. There is no water in the school. At very little cost, the pipe that passes the school could be tapped and a pipe run the necessary 20 feet or so to the school.

It is reported that the rain gets into the school porch. I can find no defect in the roof, and believe that the rain sometimes blows into the bell tower, and so finds its way into the porch.
Sir,

With reference to your letter of January 27th, No. 162-14-1 (second paragraph) I beg to say that a new floor in the Kitimat day school is absolutely required, as requested by the teacher. A detailed estimate of cost is enclosed herewith. A maple floor is asked for, costing £210.00. It is however thought that a floor of oiled grain fir would do just as well; and the cost of this would be £185.00 and this is recommended.

Then we have the matter of a coal bin, and two closets. As the building is on a hill close to a creek where Indians take water we cannot well have outside closets as with other day schools. As will be seen by enclosed sketch the teacher asks for an addition 18' x 10' at the back of the building, a lean-to containing a coal bin, and two water closets, which pipe goes past the day school down to the field Matron's residence from the residential school, and, even with a stove in this room, do not think that water closets could be kept from freezing in winter time; and for this reason, aside from the cost, cannot be recommended. Instead two chemical closets might be bought, and installed for £18.00 each.

A detailed estimate of material needed with cost of erecting the addition, total cost, £433.96 is enclosed herewith. It is prepared by Chas. E. Moore, an experienced, and reliable carpenter.

When replying to this letter kindly return estimates etc., enclosed, as I have no copy at this office. Captain Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools together with myself visited Kitimat last April, after these estimates had been sent. Kitimat has irregular, monthly mail service.

Obediently yours,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I found that 60 children are sometimes in class at the day school. Too many for the room and too many for one teacher, Miss Nelson. There were 32 on the day of my visit. Dear Sir,

Re Purchase Order #7021.

Re the above Order calling for Desks to be shipped to
J.Gillett Esq., Indian Agent, Bella Coola, B.C.
Same was immediately shipped on receipt of Order, and Invoices
mailed with shipping Bills as Instructed, dated and mailed Vancouver
29th 1938, as per our Records.

On December 16th, not having yet received payment, we sent
a letter to Mr. Gillett, advising him that we had not received our Cheque,
and owing to the Account being overdue nearly 4 Months, we would
charge Interest as is customary with our commercial accounts, and asking
him to advise us as to why the delay.

Today we received the following reply:

Dated Bella Coola December 29th, 1938

Messrs,
Nicholls & Sons,
Vancouver B.C.

Dear Sirs,

In reply to your letter of December 16th, relative to Invoices
for Desks, I may say that I did not receive them until Dec 16th although
they may have arrived here on Dec 1st or 6th as I was away from the
Office for two weeks. Evidently they had been misplaced somewhere,
either at Vancouver or the local office. The only post office Stamp on
the Envelope was Vancouver August 29th. They were transmitted to Ottawa
for Payment on December 22nd.

I regret this delay but doubt if the Department would be willing
to pay interest charges as it was not the fault of this Department. I
wish to state also that it was not your fault as the Post mark showed you
posted it Aug 29th.

Yours very truly,

(signed) J.Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Now sir the point is who is responsible for this long overdue
account. In business we have to pay carrying charges on our overdue
Accounts, and the manufacturers are holding me responsible.

You know what happens with the Government if we fail to pay
our Taxes etc. on the Due Date, well we see no reason why the Government
shouldn't do the same. If we are one day late with our Sales Tax we are
penalized.

We shall in due course send you an Overdue charge up to the
Date of receiving your Cheque.

We shall be glad to hear from you regarding this matter.

It would appear from the information I have been able to secure that the Indian Office at Bella Coola is not responsible for delay in dealing with the account beyond possibly the period December 1st to 8th during which time Mr. Gillett was absent from his office visiting Reserves. Meeting of the Kitimat Council held on June 4th, 1940 to discuss the school situation and particularly the future disposition of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home.

The Indian agent opened the meeting at 10 A.M. The Chief and all the members of the Council were present, except Joe Gray, the Secretary.

Richard Morrison, Tim Starr, Mike Shaw, James Clarkson, Ed Wesley and Don Grant present.

Tim Starr presented a petition from the Kitimat people asking for the continuance of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, pointing out the nomadic habits of these people and their mode of obtaining a livelihood, necessitating them to go long distances on their trap-lines; on logging operations and oolachan fishing.

The Agent pointed out that similar difficulties are prevalent in all the villages, and that in Bella Coola, very few of the women now accompany their men folks on trap-lines, etc.

Tim Starr moved and Mike Shaw seconded "That the Agent write the Department of Indian Affairs requesting their favourable consideration to the retention of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home." Carried unanimously.

The question of a site for the proposed new Indian Day School was discussed and it was moved by Richard Morrison and seconded by Donald Grant:

"That the Kitimat Indian Band agree to surrender one acre of land situated on and adjacent to the site of the old Kitimat Royal Temperance Society between David Grant's residence and Red Wood's residence, to the Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources for school purposes." Carried Unanimously.

Due to the urgency of this matter, the Council agreed to take the resolution in the form of a petition around the village for signatures by authorized voters.

The question of Indian labour on the proposed new school building was discussed and it was agreed that providing the Sockeye season is not profitable, the Indians are prepared to go to work in July, but if there is a fair price for Sockeye, they do not wish to commence working until August 1st.

It was also suggested that the work is distributed so that in the event of a poor fishing season, as many people as possible will benefit from this work.
Some discussion took place regarding the distribution of potatoes, since the Agent had addressed four sacks direct to Herbert McKillan in addition to one sack which he had received in the Band distribution. It was pointed out by the Agent that since Herbert had over half an acre of ground ready for planting and wished to concentrate more of his activities on farming, since seed has had to be supplied to the Band for a number of years, it was desirable that this seed be produced by the Indians themselves, or at least by some member of the Band, so that seed will not be required from outside sources in future.

It is also desirable that encouragement is given to Agricultural pursuits, as the fishing industry is becoming overcrowded, and has not in late years been very profitable.

Moved by Don Grant and seconded by Tim Starr, that the meeting adjourn. Carried.

Tm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

For Sec. of Indian Council.
The people of Kitimat have heard with concern from a responsible officer of the Indian Department that there is some likelihood that the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home will be closed in the near future. Before any action is actually taken we desire to record our protest that such action be taken at all by presenting our views on the situation.

In the first place we feel that the removal of the "Home" from the village will be a blow to the social and moral standards to which we have so far attained. Any person with insight into the standards in Indian homes and in the social life in the villages who makes more than a casual study and comparison between villages where there has never been the direct influence of a "Home" within or near the village and villages where there has been this influence over a period of years can arrive at only one conclusion. The influence of the "Home" towards better standards of living found in those places fortunate enough to have "Homes" in their midst has been a large determining factor in the whole life of those villages. No person making such observations or comparisons could fail to realize how much we would lose if the Elizabeth Long Memorial home were removed from Kitimat. We could not hope to find this influence elsewhere. Nor would our children meet but little of such influence even in the best of day schools.

While the following conditions pertain to some degree in every Indian village, we feel that Kitimat is peculiar in being forced to live a far more nomadic life than many others. There are some thirty-two trap lines owned within the Band, to the furthest of which is seventy-five miles. We estimate that the average distance for all the lines would be over thirty miles. With a four months season for marten and mink and two months trapping beaver and otter following consecutively, it can be seen that the amount of travelling that we have to do is far more than the average and that it is not possible to go out for short periods and return to the village on account of the expense of travel. Nor are we economically able to support two houses, one on the trap-line and the other in the village. Besides, in the months immediately after the New Year we get very considerable quantities of our native dried fish while trapping at the same time and our women must necessarily accompany us to take their part in its preparation. In April each year we spend three weeks at least in the preparation of our oolachan oil. We could not hope to transport the fish to the village for processing even three miles so our families have to go to the fishing grounds. While we are at oolachans we are also at our gardens which are not available in the home village. There is also a month in the fall when we have to get our dried salmon when we must go where the fish are in order to get sufficient quantity. If we could be able to make sufficient money to eliminate so much wandering in search of food then in a settled life our children would be able to take advantage of a school life which they are now able to receive through the facilities of residence in the "Home."

We are very much aware of all the benefits received at the hands of the Government and the Church. We cherish the progress we have made in all the Departments of life. We humbly petition that what we now have will not be taken from us to our detriment.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of July 4th and subsequent correspondence regarding the proposed Indian Day School at Kitimat.

After careful consideration of our requirements it is felt that a building similar to that at Bella Bella should be provided at Kitimat. The question of costs of such a structure has been gone into thoroughly with experienced carpenter builders, and my information is that it is extremely doubtful if such a building could be constructed by day labour under $7700 which amount includes $397 for electric wiring. It is understood that the contract price for the Bella Bella School, which was built nearly two years ago, was $7250, and when considering the increase in the cost of lumber, hardware and other building materials, which could be conservatively placed at 15%, and the heavier transportation costs involved because of the remoteness of Kitimat as compared with Bella Bella, which is on the direct steamship route, it will be seen immediately that the estimate of $7700 is not excessive, even considering slight changes intended to lessen costs. I could not give any assurance that the school could be constructed by day labour for less than this amount, and unless a very capable foreman carpenter is employed and very careful and constant supervision provided, the chances are the costs would be greater.

The services of Mr. Ira C. Jones, who built our schools at Pemberton and Shalalth, would be available for this work, but as he lives outside the Skeena constituency his employment might not be favorably considered. Mr. Jones has a reputation for good work and is thoroughly reliable. The contractors who built the Bella Bella School might also be available to undertake the work by day labour, but my opinion is that in any case the costs would not be less than $7700.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the construction of a new Indian Day School at Kitimat, I am enclosing herewith a memorandum dated the 10th instant from Mr. Inspector Barry, which covers fully his apparent change of opinion in respect to the urgency of this School, from which it will be observed that he considered the Ahousaht School requirements more pressing, but, as this has now been met by the decision to use the existing building at that point, it is desirable to proceed with the Kitimat construction. AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 28, 1940.

Re: Construction Kitimat School.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have for acknowledgment your Air Mail letter of the 20th instant, in which you submit additional information with respect to the construction of the above noted school.

I have today discussed with the officials of the Surveys and Engineering Branch the desirability of using the Bella Bella plans for the construction of the building at Kitimat. They have intimated that there are certain modifications in these plans that they would like to make but that these are minor modifications and can be adjusted in the course of a few hours. They have promised that they will send forward a statement of these modifications and the specifications of the Bella Bella School requested by you, just as soon as they can possibly do so.

I have also discussed the construction of this school with the Chief Executive Assistant. You are already aware that we have only $6,500 for the construction of the building. However, we can secure an additional amount by simply refusing to undertake repairs at a number of other schools where it was our intention to do such work as painting and provide certain equipment. Mr. Jackson feels that if this school is to be constructed by day labour the best possible carpenter-foreman should be secured and that construction of the building should be given capable and constant supervision. He is rather disposed to accept your recommendation that Mr. Ira C. Jones be employed to undertake this work, despite the fact that he is not a resident of the Skeena constituency.

I shall send forward to you, by Air Mail, the modified plan and specifications, just as soon as they reach me. In the meantime I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to discuss the matter with Mr. Jones and reach an understanding with him whereby he will be able to proceed with the work at the earliest possible date. I agree with Inspector Barry that the construction of this school at Kitimat and the closing of the so-called residential school now operated by the United Church will mean a substantial step forward in the education of the Indian population of that district.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,

DIRECTOR,
SURVEY & ENGINEERING BRANCH.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Major D. W. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, in which he states that in his judgment it would be desirable to use the plans of the Bella Bella Indian Day School for the construction of an Indian day school at Kitamaat. While no decision has been reached, it is just possible that the construction of this school may be undertaken by day labour.

A copy of the plans of the Bella Bella Indian Day School were sent forward to Major MacKay a few days ago. He now asks that a copy of the specifications of the Bella Bella School be forwarded to him.

It would be appreciated if you could send forward a copy of the specifications requested by Major MacKay and also any suggestions you may have to offer with respect to minor modifications that might be made in the original plan of the Bella Bella School.

Director.
Dear Sir:

Your File 162-15-5.

Replying to your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to the construction of a school on Kitimat Indian Reserve, I would advise that this matter has today been discussed at some length with Mr. I.C. Jones and he has expressed his willingness to proceed with construction immediately if authorized to do so, either by contract or by day labour as carpenter foreman.

To date the amended plans and specifications to be prepared by the Surveys & Engineering Branch have not been received.

As it is proposed to duplicate the Bella Bella Day School, I would point out that after construction it was found necessary to provide a door between the two entrance lobbies to the class rooms in order to overcome the necessity of going down stairs and through the teacher's quarters, or outside the building, to go from one class room to the other, and also to provide alternative exits in case of fire. It was also found that the joint between the plate of the wall framing and the concrete foundation was unsatisfactory and permitted water draining down the outside wall to enter the basement class rooms.

I would appreciate the Department's decision and instructions re employment of Mr. Jones if day labour is decided upon.

Yours faithfully,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Plans for Bella Bella School

With reference to your memorandum of the 27th ultimo requesting a copy of the Bella Bella School specifications and modifications of the plans for use by the Indian Affairs Branch in the erection of a day school at Kitamaat, British Columbia. I am advised that since the Bella Bella school was planned for unusual site conditions, namely, rock about two feet below the grade, it is not considered by our architects as the best plan to use under normal site conditions. As you are aware a school of similar accommodation was planned for Maria last year, and since it is considered that this plan would be more suitable, the matter was discussed with Mr. Hoey of the Indian Affairs Branch by telephone on the 28th ultimo.

Mr. Hoey concurred with our opinion in the matter and agreed to the use of the Maria School plans and specifications. I am therefore forwarding herewith for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, three sets of blue prints of plan No.741 together with one copy of the specifications for these plans.

With regard to classroom accommodation, it is understood that the school should accommodate about 70 students. Since the plan No.741 was prepared for 60 students, we have indicated on the plans the manner in which the classrooms can be extended to provide the accommodation desired.

Enclosure.

Respectfully submitted,

F.T. Miller
Chief Engineer.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Dear Sir:

Re New Kitimat Indian Day School.

I have to refer to your file 162-15-5 regarding the marginally noted construction.

A complete tabulation of the costs of the project has been made and indicates that a further sum of $1,500 will be required to complete the building. In my letter to the Department of August 20th, my file 15/2/7338, I estimated the costs of this construction at not less than $7,700 and observed that unless the conditions generally were very favorable the costs would be greater.

I would, therefore, request that a further sum of $1,500 be encumbered for this project, divided as follows:

Material $700.00
Labor $800.00

A copy of the encumbrance requisition should be forwarded at the earliest possible date, together with a cheque for $800 payable to the B.C. Indian Account to cover the costs of labor.

The latest reports would indicate that good progress is being made with the construction of this school.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re New Kitamaat Indian Day School

Your File 162-15-5.

I am forwarding herewith the following accounts of Vancouver firms on the approved list for materials purchased for the marginally noted construction as a charge against E.R.1058, dated September 20, 1940:

| Voucher | Date       | Amount   |

| 52A     | "          | $450.10 |
| 53A     | "          | $459.50 |

The Alberta Lumber Co. was the only firm manufacturing lumber in this city in a position to furnish what was required in time to meet our shipping arrangements.

The firm of Evans, Coleman & Evans was the only one in the city who could provide both materials and transportation.

Owing to the absence of proper wharf accommodation at Kitamaat to land heavy supplies, it was found necessary to arrange to have most of the materials required for the school shipped at one time by tug and scow. Evans, Coleman & Evans undertook to do this work for us. The materials were safely landed on the beach at Kitamaat and raised by highrigging equipment over the bluffs to a position where they could be transported by hand to the school site.

R.A.Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Covering purchase orders accompany each account and although in the case of the accounts of Evans, Coleman & Evans two are dated October 7th and two, October 10th, the orders were placed on the dates as per purchase orders and the goods actually shipped prior to the dates appearing on these accounts. I trust the Department will see its way clear to consider these accounts separately and the covering purchase orders sufficient to pass same for payment. In cases where firms were in a position to meet our delivery requirements, quotations were secured. It was only on condition that the scow would be loaded ready to leave Vancouver by a specified time that Evans, Coleman & Evans undertook to transport the materials to Kitamaat for us, and the placing of orders was made to meet this requirement.

To undertake any construction of importance by day labor in such a remote area as Kitamaat from this office is no easy task. However, latest reports indicate that good progress is being made with the construction of the school, despite many handicaps, not the least being continuous heavy rains during the last two weeks in October and the first week of this month.

Yours faithfully,

B.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the equipment required at the new Kitamaat Indian Day School, I would refer you to my letter of May 13th last, with which was forwarded a report on the present Kitamaat Day and Residential Schools.

There are two rooms in the basement of the new school building. Floors are of cement, and during the cold part of the winter the rooms may not be suitable for classes in Manual Training and Girls' Vocational Work. Some of the girls' work could of course be carried on in the academic classrooms, sewing and knitting for instance.

If the Manual Training is to be started immediately the school is opened some four to six double benches or at least wood for their construction would be needed, as well as twelve sets of simple tools for the boys and a set of tools for the instructor. Mr. Doucet of the Department has I believe prepared a list of suitable tools but I have not as yet been supplied with a copy of this list. If it is not available later I could no doubt prepare a list of suitable tools for this particular school.

A Singer sewing machine will be required at the opening of the school for the use of the older girls. Later wool carders, weaving frames, and a spinning machine similar to those used in the Cowichan Agency may be needed.

It is very difficult for me to state in a definite way just what equipment is required now for the Manual Training and Vocational Rooms, as so much depends on the staff of the school. Manuals also will lie in the hands of the United Church officials no doubt, and I have no idea whether it is their intention to nominate a married man as senior teacher and Manual Training Instructor with a girl as Primary Teacher, or whether the school will be placed in the charge of two girls. In the latter case the immediate provision of Manual Training tools would not appear to be necessary.

The teachers' residence consists of two small bedrooms, a small living room and a small kitchen. If a married man were to be appointed as Principal, I do not know whether the Primary teacher would live in the school or have to board and room in the Mission House.

In any case we should provide the minimum necessary furniture for the teachers' rooms in the new school building.
The furniture for the teachers' rooms might well be similar to that provided for the Boothroyd Day School, except that at Kitamaat we shall have to include a kitchen stove and some living room furniture.

In my letter of May 13th I suggested that the furniture for Kitamaat would cost about $300.00 and as prices are going up all the time I am not able to in any way reduce this provisional estimate.

The numbers of each size of desk needed for the classrooms were given in my previous letter on this subject, and I may say that it is essential that the arrangement of desks in the two rooms outlined in that letter be followed in detail so that full use can be made of the existing desks in the present Kitamaat School.

In conclusion I would suggest that for the present the necessary desks and furniture for the teacher's rooms be provided, the electric light plant taken over from the present Kitamaat Indian Residential School if it is possible to obtain possession of it, water brought into the new building from the new pipe line, and the Singer sewing machine supplied, while the provision of Shop Training tools, lumber, etc., be deferred till we know that an instructor is available, or till after the first inspection of the school, probably early in the 1942-43 Fiscal Year.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Yours truly,

I have had an enquiry concerning Kitamaat, as to whether there are quarters for the teachers in the new school and, if so, whether they are furnished. I presume that, if there are quarters, they will be sufficient to accommodate two teachers.

INSPECTION OF BELLA COOLA AGENCY

OCTOBER 1941.

KITIMAT INDIAN RESERVE NO.2

SCHOOL. The new day school is functioning very well and at present has about 47 children in the junior grade under Miss Wilson and about 35 in the senior grade under Miss Leith. Both of these teachers appeared competent and had their rooms under excellent control. The children appeared very happy, well dressed and nourished.

The new school appeared satisfactory in every respect, although it was observed that here, as at Bella Bella with a school of the same design, that the red roof paint had washed down with the rain over the white walls, marring the appearance. More than this, the condition suggested the necessity of some roof gutter along these sections of the eaves in order to prevent decay of that part of the building. It would not require more than about 50 feet of this gutter, the cost of which would be quite small.

There is no wood shed for the school and at present during the rainy season, it is necessary to store the wood in one of the basement class rooms. In order to construct a wood shed it would be necessary to level another piece of the school site but this should be done in order to give the fuel a chance to dry out.

Jas. Coleman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
May 4, 1948.

Dear Sir:

Excerpts from Inspector Coleman's report on his inspection of the Bella Coola Agency have just been brought to my attention and in this regard I desire to refer particularly to his report on the Kitimat School. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of the 50 feet of gutter recommended by the Inspector.

Regarding the necessity for supplying a new woodshed, please let me have an estimate of the cost of material and labour.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of May 13th, No. 215-2-6291 re wood shed for the Kitamaat Indian Day School, would advise that I took this matter up on a recent visit to this village.

The size proposed by Mr. Christie was a shed, 18 x 24 with an 8 foot high wall, this would be enclosing the power house in one corner.

The bill for material can probably be ascertained more readily from your office, as there is no place here where it can be purchased.

Would recommend putting a corrugated iron roof on this building, as it would lessen the fire hazard, and would be cheaper in the long run.

The space near the school is very limited, and a certain amount of excavation work will have to be done, as the buildings are on the side of a hill, and this will run up the labor costs, of construction. Would recommend that cement posts be put under sills, to make the job more permanent.

There is also the floor in the power house to be considered the present floor is only dirt, and this should be cemented, to prevent fire hazard. The power house is all covered in corrugated iron, with roof of same material.

The estimated cost of labor, erecting building, carrying material from dock, and putting in cement posts is $125.00.

Bill of material needed is enclosed, in triplicate.

Dear Sir,

While at Kitumant recently I noticed that there were several things needing attention around the new school. First, the cook stove in the teachers' residence is set close to the wall and there is no protection over the wall board behind the stove; found that the wall board was so badly charred with the heat that it was crumbling and there is a great danger of setting the building on fire. Would suggest that a heavy asbestos sheet 54" by 28" by 2" thick be fitted on the wall behind the stove and pipe.

Also needs a reducing stove-pipe 7" to 6".

Fire protection: there are no fire extinguishers in the building and while there I tried the water hydrant outside the building and found that there was insufficient pressure to bring the water to bring the water up to the school. Would suggest that two large size Tyrone fire extinguishers be purchased and installed in the school.

Also noticed there are no ladders either on the roof or on the side of the building. Would therefore suggest that material for four ladders be purchased, two for the roof and two for the side of the building.

Would also suggest that roof should be painted as the first coat which was applied during the winter months when shingles were wet did not penetrate and consequently a large part of this has washed away.

Noticed also that there are no blinds for the teachers' residence. Amount needed, eight blinds 36x44 inches, and four blinds 36x56 inches.

Date: November 18th, 1942
Dear Sir:

The school situation at Kitamaat is not very satisfactory, owing to the large number of children who live at Butedale Cannery, with their parents, during the herring canning season, leaving only about one quarter of the children of school age in the village. Took up the matter of school with the manager at Butedale, but unfortunately the regular manager was away on his holidays, and the man in charge was there only temporarily, he did however get in touch with the head office in Vancouver, but upon my return from Kitamaat, he had not had any reply.

Miss Vermilyea, sent to Kitamaat to teach the Junior room was sick upon my arrival, and she informed me that she had sent in her resignation to the W.M.S., and under the circumstances, it was probably just as well, as there were not enough children attending school, to warrant two teachers, Mrs Waywell seemed to be very efficient, and she had the best control in the class room, that I have seen in any Indian day school, so hope that she makes a success of her work there.

Your obedient servant,

T.A. Leavelton,
Acting Indian Agent.
Bella Coola Agency

November 19th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

A stay of six days at Kitamaat was necessary, owing to the late arrival of the monthly boat, and as there was some material for the Kitamaat woodshed aboard, I had to await the arrival of the boat.

The ground for the woodshed was leveled out, and holes for the foundation posts were dug, and the forms for cement posts were placed, and cement poured in the corner posts before left. Cold weather set in at the time, and it is doubtful if anything could be done with the floor in the powerhouse, as there was a possibility that the cement would freeze before setting.

Your obedient servant,
T.A. Levelton,
Acting Indian Agent.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's application of the 16th ultimo for authority to expend $75.00 for the fencing of the grounds in front of the new Indian Day School. According to Mr. Inspector Coleman who recently visited Kitamaat, the school site was excavated from a rather steep side hill sufficiently to erect the building and leave a few feet of level ground in front of the school but this cut and fill left a hazard for children playing around the school during the recreation period.

Unfortunately, we have not succeeded in getting teachers for this school and there are none in sight. Consequently, the fencing is not urgent unless the Department would prefer to have the work carried out during the present fiscal year at a time when the Indians are mostly in the village. If funds are available, I am prepared to recommend approval of the application.

November 19th, 1943

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Application for grant of $75.00 for land improvements, Kitamaat

Ref. your 182-4056 of May 1st, 1943, it is proposed to spend $75.00 made up of 120 labour hours at 62½ cents an hour for the cutting of material necessary to put in a crib and a neat pole fence immediately in front of the new day school at Kitamaat where there is at present a rather hazardous drop should young children venture too near. Present brush and slash would have to be cleared away, and a log crib put in, and the area fenced.

Further work would have to be undertaken in succeeding fiscal years, and eventually a very pleasant area could be created, with its consequent training values to the children.

The Council will take responsibility for supervision of this work and they will have enough nails on hand of a large size from their wharf construction to take care of the fence built this fiscal year.

If sanctioned, an accountable cheque would be appreciated, so that the men could be paid off when the village is visited by the Agent.

F. Earl Anfield,

I enclose herewith application of Mr. Acting Indian Agent Levelton for renovation of the floors at Kitamaat Indian Day School, which he states are beginning to get worn in places.

It is noted that he recommends that this renovation be carried out by means of an application of boiled linseed oil but, in my opinion, this material is not satisfactory where floors, etc., have to carry the traffic incidental to school use, and I would recommend that the surfaces be given a two-coat application of Renetrum, manufactured by the Treco Mfg. Co. and found very satisfactory for this purpose. As this floor finish would cost $24.30 for five gallons, f.o.b. Vancouver, this amount being considered sufficient, the total cost of the job with labour at $15.00 would amount to $39.30 instead of the $27.00 estimated by Mr. Levelton, and, if funds can be provided, I would recommend approval of the application on that basis.

Re attached Vouchers #268 and 271 dated Nov.3/45 for three barrels gasoline, 1 can (4 gallon) lub oil and freight charges Butedale to Kitamaat, the following explanation is given for the purchase of this fuel.

There is no regular passenger and freight service from Butedale to Kitamaat, and the Indians, who have only small gas boats, charge $5.00 to $7.50 per drum, depending on weather conditions, to freight gasoline into Kitamaat.

After weeks of negotiations, arrangements were finally made to have a steamer take a load of lumber and freight into Kitamaat and as time did not permit applying for authority from the Department, I instructed the steamer to pick up three barrels gasoline and a tin of lub oil at Butedale and take them into Kitamaat, thus making sure of a winter's supply of fuel for the lighting plant at the School and Teacherage.

Under the circumstances, it is hoped the Department will sanction the action taken.

F. Earl Anfield,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Kitamaat Indian Day School
Gutter flashings & down spouts
with drainage

At the time the above named school was built no eaves-troughing was installed, as a result the building now presents a poor appearance where the rain from the roof has beaten against the walls and run down. There are particularly bad waterfalls at both doorways owing to the construction of the roof. As I have put an item in the estimates for painting this building next year, I am of the opinion that the guttering should be installed this fall.

I have been endeavoring to secure price quotations on metal guttering and down pipes but so far without success. Reliance Lumber Co., Vancouver have quoted on wooden 4 x 4 Clear Fir Gutter at $122.50 per M. There would be 280 lineal feet required which would work out at less than $50.00. It will be necessary to secure 150 lineal feet of 2" metal down pipe with 12 elbows to complete the work and perhaps you may have more success in finding this piping than I have had. For attaching the wooden gutter, 5 lbs. of 5" nails would be required with 1 lb. of 2½" finishing nails for finishing corners etc.

Owing to the roof construction, the greater part of the water will come off on the east side of the building at the rear against the hill side. Because of the heavy nature of the soil, drainage should be supplied and this will require 90 feet of 3" tiling on each side of the building. That is, one drain to go on the north side running east to west, emptying through the cribbing to the west of the building and another 90 feet paralleling it on the south side of the building. I have been endeavoring to locate tiling, but that too seems scarce. T. G. McBride & Co., Main St., Vancouver have not yet answered my enquiry to them and it is possible they may be hoping to find and supply this tile.

(over)
If this fails, we might have more success in having one large shipment sent in about October to handle as much as possible of our freight for Kitimat. However since the materials are scarce, it is not too soon to place orders now to be ready for that date.

Thank you for your help in this matter. Shipping instructions will go forward when further arrangements have been made at Butedale.

WPP/D

W. P. Pruden,
Indian Agent.
Kitamaat, B.C.
June 15, 1947.

I, the undersigned, undertake to attach new flashings, gutters and downpipes on to the Kitamaat Day School for the sum of $134.00.

I intend to hire two men to help me and I expect to get this work done in one week.

"David Shaw"

Re: Kitamaat Day School fire ladders

This building has never been supplied with fire ladders and these should be put in place without delay.

While at Kitamaat in June I discussed the requirements with Mr. Robinson and tried to locate someone to do the work. It seems that in 1941 some ladder material was shipped in, but no one could be found to do the work and when Mr. Robinson came to the school, only one piece of ladder standard 16 feet long remained. He put this away in the wood shed, but I examined it and found it no longer suitable for building ladders and authorized Mr. Robinson to use it in constructing a door for the wood shed which he proposed to lock, as wood had been disappearing. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Kitamaat Indian Day School Teacherage

I am enclosing herewith a letter from Indian Superintendent Fruden requesting authority to purchase a cook stove for the above named teacherage.

It will be noted that the old stove in the teacherage has given considerable trouble for several years and is now beyond repair. In view of this, and in order that the teacher will not be inconvenienced any longer than necessary, I have ordered a suitable range at a cost of $125.20 to be forwarded as soon as possible.

I trust that my action in this instance is approved and I would recommend that the expenditure of $125.20 plus freight will be authorized by the Department as a charge against the Educational Vote.

[Signature]

J.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

[Stamp]
Mr. W. S. Arnell, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Kitamaat Teacherage Furnishings

The cook stove at the above teacherage has given trouble for several years. On each of our trips to Kitamaat in the past year Mr. Leviton has spent an hour or more trying to adjust it to work satisfactorily. New plates and firebacks were purchased but when fitted in, on our last trip, these were found to be not quite satisfactory since the frame of the stove was warped. It was hoped however that the stove would be serviceable for a while.

I now have a telegram from Mr. Robinson to report that the grates have collapsed and support for grates and oven top are burned through. The stove is therefore no longer usable. The teacher and nurse will be making shift on a small heating stove in the dispensary. This will be most inconvenient.

Please ship at once one wood and coal burning range with water reservoir and warming drawer, suggestion: Watsons Vol-6116. This should be shipped by Union Steamships and addressed to Kitamaat Indian Day School, Kitamaat, via Hatzicola, B. C. There will be a charge for transportation from Hatzicola to Kitamaat which I will pay in cash and voucher in addition to regular Union steamship freight bill.

I will be in Hatzicola on my return from Kitamaat on October 14th. If arrival of stove could be prior to that date it would facilitate arrangements for early shipment to Kitamaat.

[Signature]

[Name]
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

Dear Sir:

Re. Kitamaat School Maintenance

In reply to your 2-11-3-(162) of 30th June, 1949, Mr Wesley has relinquished his tender for the work of painting the above school. He and his wife were both offered highly remunerative employment at Butedale, and I rather believe it was a bit too much for him to watch the rest of the band leave the village and leave him behind. He therefore begged off the obligation when I met him at Butedale on 25th of June.

I am attaching a tender from Mr. Micah Shaw who is also a member of the Kitamaat Band. I note what you have said regarding day work for this project. It will be realized that this office cannot maintain a time keeper at Kitamaat to verify labor returns. Mr. Shaw is a reliable man and I would normally accept his statement, but the matter of day work is further complicated by the fact that Mr. Shaw is under medical direction to take certain rest periods each day, hence his hours will be irregular. A number of his friends have assured me that they will be at Kitamaat frequently during the summer and will give him voluntary assistance to complete this work. He has a wife and three small children, as well as an aged father to support and is naturally concerned about next winter.
Re. Kitamaat School Maintenance, Contd.

He had been canvassing the local logging camps for employment and it was largely to prevent him from taking more strenuous work that his friends urged me to offer him the paint work. This may also have been a factor in Mr. Wesley's relinquishing the job. I am satisfied that Mr. Shaw can complete the work with the aid of his wife, an older married daughter who will be living at his home for a time this summer and his many friends who have offered to aid. This is the only opportunity now available to have this work completed, since none of the able bodied men will stay in the village during the summer. Mr. Shaw is an intelligent man and before becoming a partial invalid was known as an efficient workman. I therefore recommend that his tender be accepted.

No doubt paint has already moved forward addressed to Mr. Wesley. This will be satisfactory since Mr. Wesley is at Butedale and has promised to look out for the shipment and have it sent up to Mr. Shaw at Kitamaat by a fish packer working that way. Mr. Malcolm, Manager at Butedale has also promised to look out for the shipment and expedite its transhipment to Kitamaat.

Yours truly,

W.J. Pruden
Supt. Indian Agency

Re: Kitamaat Day School, Maintenance

Attached is tender in quadruplicate for the work of painting and decorating the above school building throughout, both classrooms, halls, stairs, two basement rooms and four roamed teacherage, all surfaces both inside and out.

The outside of this building is in particularly poor condition. It was originally painted in the winter and as a result the paint has checked, crumbled and washed off badly. It will have to be thoroughly wire brushed before painting. The inside has reached a condition where decorating is needed throughout.

I have been endeavoring for about two years to persuade someone to take this work. Mr. Ed Wesley, a member of the Kitamaat Band, has at last agreed to forego the fishing season in order to get this work done and is now waiting at Kitamaat to receive the paint and supplies. BELLA COOLA AGENCY.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF NOVEMBER, 1941.

Bella Coola, B.C.
December 1, 1941.

Practically all the Kitimat Indians were at home and the new school was well attended. A meeting was held with the Council on various business matters at which Inspector Coleman discussed the revival of Indian handicraft and boat building. It was noted that the new missionary at this point, Rev. Basil Hartley had been taking a class of boys in the school basement in gas engines and their operations. This kind of co-operation by the missionary will no doubt be much appreciated by the Department as other missionaries on our Reserves in Bella Coola Agency have shown a deplorable lack of interest in the young people under their care.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 15th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have noticed with interest the report of a meeting of the Council held at Bella Coola. I would be pleased if you would interview the missionary mentioned therein, Rev. Basil Hartley, and find out if he is qualified to carry out organized instruction in woodwork, combustion engines and light metal work.

If this man were qualified to carry on instruction, I would be pleased to furnish directions and a course of study and, possibly, slight remuneration for his trouble. On receiving your report, I will give this matter further consideration.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Your File 162-15-11

Letter Dated Feb. 15, 1942.

It has not been possible to visit Kitimat during the past two months as the Departmental Launch is not in first class shape and the weather is often very stormy at this time of year.

Mr. Hartley, however, was written regarding his qualifications to carry out instructions in woodwork, combustion engines, and light metal work.

The following is his reply quoted from a letter dated January 3, 1942:

"Many thanks for your letter of December 30, which had a perilous trip up here, but came in yesterday, after David Duncan's boat had opened a couple of seams in the pounding seas just below Coste Island.

Regarding the courses you speak of, I think that I could handle any of them. The time element plays its part - the boys are keen as anything, and most enjoyable to work with; but yours truly has precious little spare time. We are in the throes of negotiations with a view to getting the original status of our Post Office restored, whereby we should be freed from the tiresome and time-consuming business of issuing money orders, but that may take some time yet. However, we might be able to work out something, I think that for the time being, while our time is so very limited, that we might accomplish most if we began with the older lads, who would be most likely to find immediate application for their 'newly-acquired' knowledge.

I have taken the Diesel Course offered by Hemphills, some years back when they were first opening up in Vancouver, and..."
January 25, 1943.

While there I put in some time teaching acetylene welding, which would be my choice of a trade. I don't suppose the Department will be able to see its way to equipping us along that line, at least until after the war, but for practical usefulness there would be few trades that we could introduce that would be better. Of course, there would be no object in making a community of welders, but it would offer a very useful trade to a few, for the days when the fishing isn't so good, and we will be hard put to it to help the people adapt themselves to changing conditions.

I will try to find out how many we could line up for a course - the boys are all pretty fair at operating gas engines, but could stand some help on repairs and maintenance, and might be encouraged to advance to diesel work."

It would appear from Mr. Hartley's letter that he is well qualified to follow a course of study in the subjects you mentioned and I think the Department will do well to avail themselves of Mr. Hartley's ability in this line of work which is of the greatest importance to the Coast Indians, operating, as all of them do, their own gas boats, and also in view of the increased demands for men with such training in War Industries.

I would respectfully suggest that a course of study is sent immediately. Mr. Hartley does not mention what remuneration he wishes but perhaps the Department has a standard rate by the day or hour for such instruction.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

TO: MO
Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the work being done by Mr. Hartley at Kitimat. While there is no doubt that Mr. Hartley is making a real attempt to benefit the Indian boys, at the same time I feel it advisable to postpone any definite action until you have had an opportunity of visiting Kitimat. At the time of your next inspection there you should carefully study Mr. Hartley's work and write to me again.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Agent,

At a meeting of our Mission Board held Sept. 28, 1915 I brought before the members your letter requesting me to aid in securing a suitable teacher for the Indian Bay School at Kitkatla.

The Board decided to request Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Mustard to go to Kitkatla, and live in our Mission house for the two school quarters ending Dec. and March. Mr. Mustard has had a College training and Mrs. Mustard has been trained as a nurse, and is good at teaching calisthenics.

Gurd went with them to introduce them. As Mr. Gurd assured the Board that from March to October the village is practically deserted we only engaged Mr. & Mrs. Mustard for the two quarters.

It appears that the Conservative Association had recommended the teacher for the Massett school, but when we arranged with them we understood that the teacher of last year had returned, which is correct, though since we have heard that he may be leaving.

In order to save time I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Iver Fouger, Indian Agent, hoping that he will concur in our action as it is extremely difficult to get teachers to go to such out-of-the-way Indian villages.

To the Minister of Education

Honourable Sir,

I am enclosing a letter which was written by a native of this village regarding the subject of education. The letter is singularly worded, but perhaps will explain itself. I am sending it just as it was handed to me. I was not present at the meeting; it was held on a Saturday. I was too busy.

But I attach supreme importance to the subject of which it treats. Nothing in my estimation will be of such permanent value to Indians as teaching.

In fact, I see no hope for them outside the sphere of education. What is required is a school conducted similarly to one at Metlakatla, only on a smaller scale.

To me it is decidedly unreasonable as well as undesirable to compel children to go out of their own village to be taught.

Could you not erect a Boarding School here, where a dozen of the brightest, most promising youths of both sexes might be boarded, taught & disciplined?

The Kitkatlas are a fine race of Indians, an sometimes called 'the Kaffirs of the Coast'. Exceedingly energetic, bright & loyal. The number of residents is about 250.

The multiplication of schools of instruction is one of the most most praiseworthy efforts put forth by the Department for the benefit of the rising generation of Indians.

And when the Indians meet together as a body, they the Department to lift them up out...
Of their ignorance, is a clear sign that they mean what they say that the appeal when Daniel wrote be much appreciated.

There are three things which entitle them to your kindly consideration:

1. The Kitkatlas are essentially a hunting tribe. They are away for the purpose seven months out of twelve. They leave early in February for their different hunting grounds. They return for a week or two in April then leave in large numbers to hunt for seal off Bonilla Island. After which they go to the west coast of Vancouver Island for sea otter, returning to their village in September where they remain until July to see year after year.

It is obvious that most of the instruction imparted is lost on account of their being away so much from their village.

2. The Kitkatlas are an exclusive tribe. They have little in common with the Indians of which family they are a branch, a chief branch.

They object to the placing of their children in schools away from their homes. In some cases, children in these schools have died there buried before their parents heard anything about them. The school nearest here viz. Metlakatla will never be any great benefit to the children of this place.

I might have prevailed upon me or even to send their children at Metlakatla School, but that institution was too far to receive any more.

3. The Kitkatlas are a progressive tribe. They have made considerable material progress all their old dirty narrow uncomfortable huts have been exchanged for wide spacious ones all their old dwellings associated as they were.
