Dear Sir,

I have taken the liberty of writing to you personally rather than through the usual channels, which I employed on two other occasions, in order to put my application before you.

I have been teacher at this village for 2 years and am receiving remuneration at the rate of $75 per month for the period of the actual teaching months, namely 9 or 10 as the case may be.
The object of this letter is to ask you to increase my salary to £900 per annum.

I base my request on the following facts:

I believe the Dept. to be satisfied with my work as Teacher, judging by Mr. Carson's attitude. The Natives themselves are also very pleased with the progress made.

I have not only the children of School Age on my register but am teaching a class of infants numbering 13 or so.

Bishop du Vernet, for whom I do the missionary work gratis, has on several occasions expressed himself very pleased with the social...
and religious progress made during my residence.

Over and above the school work I do the dispensing & medical work, which has greatly reduced the number of really serious cases of illness.

I have set the example of garden culture & poultry keeping which influenced the natives to take up these pursuits last year on a small scale. This year they are going in more heavily.

Mrs Oliver & myself have a very personal influence over the natives as we have made it our business to ingratiate ourselves with them.
So much for the work, the quality of which I will let you judge for yourself sir, or reference can be made to Mr. Touguer, Mr. Gairns, Bishop du Vernet, and a number of people in Prince Rupert.

I wish to point out to you sir, that this place is 50 miles from our Post Office + Stores at Prince Rupert, without any communication from or to the outside except by our own Gasoline Launches. Thus the cost of living here is far greater than elsewhere. We have to pay Prince Rupert prices which are about 25% higher than Vancouver or Victoria and over and above
5. This figure the freight to Kitamaat costs approximately $16.00 per trip if I use my own launch or 50¢ per parcel if goods are delivered by the natives.

There is no house provided consequently I have to pay rent, neither is fuel provided for my own use, this item costs me about $60.00 p.a.

Thus you will see that as a married man it is a real struggle to get along on the present basis.

We have no white residents nearer than Prince Rupert.
I have tried to augment my salary by getting work for myself on my boat during July Aug & Sept but have met with no success as no one seems to require a man for so limited a period. The companies require one to start in May & continue till October.

I notice that at Masset (where the school is larger) that the Dept pay $900 p.a., plus house and fuel and an assistant part of time.

Thereafter paying rent $120, fuel $60 it only leaves a net income of about $540 or $44 per month.
May I ask you, Sir,
to consider the above statement & if you are satisfied that the nature or the work & the circumstances contained herein warrant the increasing of the remuneration, I dare hope that you will see your way to advising the Department to make the adjustment.

I am aware that you are an exceedingly busy man and I have endeavoured to make this as brief as possible but at the same time to lay all the facts before you, therefore I must ask you to overlook the fact that I have been unable to keep
This letter under seven pages.

I wish to thank you for any effort which you may make on our behalf.

I remain Sir,

Your obedient servant

Geo Oliver

Dear Sir,

I am desirous of leaving this Northern country for reasons enumerated below and as Mr Oliver and myself both wish to remain servants of your Department I thought it best to put the matter before you and to ask for your kind consideration of the case which I will state as briefly as I can.

As Agent Touques jurisdiction is only over this Northern part of B.C., I conclude that it is in order to write to you direct instead of putting the correspondence through his office.

I am expecting him to visit here shortly, however, I will then tell him that I have written to you.

This particular Reserve, as you no doubt know, is by its geographical position without any protection from the fearful storms which are peculiar to this locality during the winter months, added to which the rainfall locally is extremely
heavy and these two climatic con-
ditions have seriously affected my
health.

I have been suffering this last
eighteen months or so from Bronchial
Catarrh and last December I was
extremely ill with Bronchitis + but
for my wife's splendid nursing
I should not have recovered.

I have however entirely got
over this sickness but have no wish
to repeat the experience.

We shall have four or three
years here this coming September
and we are beginning to feel the
effects of the isolation very much.

There are no whites nearer than
45 miles (Prince Rupert), no mail
service + no communication with
civilization except by our own
gasoline launch which we are
unable to use during the winter
on account of the storms.

We have had no visit from
anyone either missionary boat or
otherwise since the Agent and
School Inspector paid us a
visit last April (11 months ago).

In the Summer we are of
course entirely alone from June to
Sep or Oct; but even then we are
not able to go away visiting because
once before the house was entered
+ things stolen.
This isolation has affected us both so that we have become cranky; as the saying is, from the want of having some of our own kind to visit occasionally.

We like the work we are engaged in & would be sorry to leave the Service, for this reason I ask you if you could possibly transfer us further South, into the interior, or back East.

During my residence in Canada I have never been troubled with any throat, chest or lung complaint until living in Southern B.C.

Should you not have a vacancy for Scholastic work you may have some other position at Ottawa or elsewhere which I could satisfactorily fill as I am fairly versatile on the part with statistical, accountancy & executive work.

I have not yet mentioned to his Lordship the Bishop my wish to leave here and shall not do so until I have a reply from you.

I am acting for him in the capacity of Lay Reader & have charge of this Village.

Should you desire to have an interview with me in respect to this appeal it would give me
much pleasure to come to Ottawa and call on you at your office, at the end of the School Term, or at your instructions I could leave the School in Mr. Oliver's charge (seeing that the attendance is light, many pupils now being absent with their parents at the hunting camps) and visit you at an earlier date.

Thanking you in anticipation of a favorable consideration

I remain,

Through the kindness of Mr. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, I have heard that the positions of teacher and field matron to the Indians at Kitkatla are vacant, and as Mr. Douglas informed me that he has recommended my wife and myself for the respective positions, I wish to make formal application to you for same.

Mr. Cairns informs me that Mr. Matthews who applied for the position some time ago, has since accepted a school in the Fraser Valley. On that account I advised him to write to you in connection with the positions.

I am a trained teacher and have had a good deal of experience both in the old country and here, although at the present time I am superintending the Mail Order Dept. & the Woodward Dept. Store, of this city. My wife and myself both prefer
an outdoor life and as teaching is more to my liking than Commercial work, I should be glad if you will give us the opportunity of filling the positions at Kilkatta. We are both musical and have one boy, a few months old.

Mr. Burns mentioned also that the Dept. would pay our fares & transportation charges. However, as he has gone to arrange for a boat for a trip we could arrange for that. Is the house at Kilkatta furnished? And do the boats call every month or is there any set service to the island? Mr. Douglas has written at your suggestion to Bishop Du Vernet and we await his letter.

If you find everything satisfactory and can arrange to have us go little, I would be obliged if you would wire me collect. Yours truly,

R.R. Johnson

Sir,

In my report on the Kitkatla Indian Day School for the month of May last, I gave the Department the names of Neera Kent and Giggle, two likely applicants for the position of teacher for this school. The names were suggested by His Grace the Archbishop of Caledonia. As I have heard nothing as to this recommendation, I would like to be informed as to whether the Department is able to consider the suggestions offered by the Archbishop.

I have written to the Inspector of Schools for British Columbia with a view to obtaining from him any further suggestions for this school, in connection with which a matron is also required.

The difficulty attending the appointments for Kitkatla is that there is only active work for a teacher and matron for five months out of the year. Both His Grace Archbishop Du Vernet and Rural Dean T.W. Rushbrook are on the lookout for suitable persons for this village, but up to the present they have not been able to find them.

Under the circumstances mentioned, would you be kind enough to let me know what the Department considers

considered it would be able to offer in the way of salary for the period mentioned, duties to commence October 1st next, and to terminate March 31st 1920 and each season onward. It does not seem reasonable to me to have the Department pay two salaries at the usual monthly rate for the whole year when only five months' work is done by the appointees.

I would suggest that the Department offer $100.00 per month and bonus of $20.00 for a teacher, and $50.00 per month and bonus of $20.00 for a matron, both to engage for five months in each year. The Kitikmeut Indians, being anxious that I should visit their village before the spring season of people for hunting and trapping, I was able to make the trip on the 4th. This village is very much out of the way, being situated on a remote island about fifty miles north of Prince Rupert. The people depend almost entirely upon hunting in the winter and salmon fishing in the summer, for their living. They are not as progressive as other Indians in the Agency, in fact - this being my first visit - I was struck by the neglected appearance of the place. There being no resident Missionary, the people have no leader to encourage them along progressive lines. I found a few cases of sickness, especially among the children, without medical aid beyond what the people are able to do for themselves. The School Teacher does not understand the dispensing of medicines, and is, therefore, not supplied with any.

Dear Mr. Cairns:

I have to thank you for your very kind, and encouraging letter of Nov. 26th/26; I did not tell you in my last, that I am working here under an handicap; as several Indians showed their surprise at my being here, on their return from the Canneries; as they were expecting to find the old teacher here, (Mrs. Dampre). This month they have had a meeting in one of their houses, and made a cash collection, and will try to get her to come back; the Parents have never really stood behind me, in sending the children.

The Indian Agent was here January 20th, and spoke to them about the poor attendance; and told the newly elected Police, they should make that one of their duties, to look after truants; so that this week, there has been a better attendance; So one day, when every seat is full, & was occupied, so that I cannot have more than that number; my daughter in Vancouver, is sending me the regulation Corrective Strip, and I think I shall have to use it, as some of the older ones, are getting unruly; and if I speak to them, and then talk down the room, they make ugly faces behind my back.

I have already been asked by more than one, how much longer, I am going to stay on the Island; and I just simply say, I do not expect to be in Rupert before next June, and then they go away.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE KITKATLA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. DATE OF INSPECTION MAY 13, 1936.

Name of teacher: Rev. M. H. Lawrence.

The Rev. M. H. Lawrence was trained at Camrose Normal School, and holds an Alberta Second Class Interim Certificate. He states that he has had some six years experience in Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba. He was at the Hazelton Indian Day School for a year, and was moved to his present position in September 1934 on the nomination of the Right Reverend Bishop Rix of Prince Rupert.

Mr. Lawrence attended the Provincial Summer School in Victoria in 1934 taking courses in Primary Work and Indian & Rural Problems. In 1935 he took a course in singing at the same summer school.

A very complete report was made on this teacher last September. He does not appear to have improved in any respect. I do not consider that he will ever make a successful teacher. He simply does not know how to teach or control a school, and nothing that I have been able to do has made any difference. Mr. Lawrence would not appear to be in possession of any permanent standing as a teacher in any Province after some eight years experience in four Provinces. I understand that this man is being removed from his present position at the end of June, and it is, therefore, useless to make any further remarks with regard to his lack of professional knowledge. I do not consider him a good influence in the village and would ask that he be excluded from residence in an Indian village in B.C., after he gives up his present appointment at the end of June. It is very difficult to understand why Mr. Lawrence was ever permitted to take charge of an Indian school in B.C.

* * *

During my inspection of the work, Doctor McQuarrie carried out a medical inspection of the children. He asked me if I minded him sending home a number of the children who were very dirty. I considered that as Medical Officer he might do as he wished. The teacher afterwards said that the Doctor had sent home THE BEST READERS. Some of the children left in the Intermediate Grades made me feel quite ill with dirty habits, a girl blowing her nose in her dirty dress, ETC.

Mr. Indian Agent Collison was also present for part of the inspection.

The school itself was in a satisfactory state, floor having been recently washed I believe, but the pupils were anything but clean. To make it possible to have the children clean at least their hands and faces, I have recommended the teacher requisition a wash basin, two towels, a bucket for water, and a drinking cup.

I drew Mr. Indian Agent's attention to the fact that the fine set of Hiproads Readers supplied to the school last September were in a terrible state, just falling to pieces with pages all out of order, Etc. Little or no care has been taken of the material supplied.

Possibly as the teacher is leaving it will be sufficient to state that the present standing of this school is "Very Poor". The teacher's control is nearly hopeless.

Dear Sir:

The work of a teacher in this village is greatly handicapped by the school building. It stands on one of the poorest sites in the village, but the site is surrounded by houses and is within a few yards of high water mark. Dear Mr. Anfield,

Mr. Cecil Caster passed me your recent letter last evening. Mr. Campbell and I have been looking over the places in need of teachers and are unable to decide just where we would be of the most service.

Mr. Campbell has had no teacher training and only a grade school education; however he has traveled a great deal and read extensively. He has homesteaded in Saskatchewan and here in British Columbia. The past three years we have been out together carrying on Vacation Bible Schools in isolated districts. He enjoys the work with the children and is a great help to me.

We are not sure just what his duties would be at Hartley Bay and whether he has had sufficient education for the duties required.

I graduated from Deering High School Portland, Maine in 1910 and from the Portland Training School for Teachers in 1911.

That fall I accepted a position as Primary
teacher in Yarmouth, Maine and remained there for four and a half years when I resigned to accept a position in the city of Everett, Massachusetts. I held this position for five years until my marriage when I again resigned.

During the time of my teaching, I took summer courses at Gorham Normal School, Gorham, Maine, and at the State Normal at Hyannis, Massachusetts, also a course offered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Board of Education, Dept. of University Extension, on Methods of Teaching English to Immigrants.

I hold a Life Certificate for Maine issued at Augusta, Maine Aug. 1918 and was on leave of office in Massachusetts.

After my marriage I taught for four years in rural schools in Saskatchewan and for one term on a Temporary Certificate here in British Columbia, until the Board could find a permanent teacher.

I am enclosing copies of letters written by members of the School Board in Yarmouth, Maine to Mr. Whitney, Superintendent of Schools in Everett, Massachusetts, and a letter from Mr. Whitney written at the time I left Everett.

With the exception of my work in the rural schools in Saskatchewan, I have taught lower grades entirely and for that reason the school in Ajannah appeals strongly to me as I much prefer the
work in the Primary Grade.

Mr. Campbell would like to be of real service to the community to which he goes to the position at Hartley Bay. Appeals to him if you feel that his many years of experience in farming on the prairies and working in the lumber and trapping in the north country would be sufficient for the work required of him.

Several years ago Miss Margaret Fraser wrote me asking if we would be at all interested in coming to Kitkatla. Of course Mr. Campbell would be unable to take the upper grade work there, and I am really a Primary teacher. We have heard of Jane Victoria and her work and it would be nice to work with her.

We both feel that knowing our training and experience and the needs of the different places there that you will be far more able to decide just where we could be of the most service. We are both willing to go wherever you think best if you still need our service.

I suppose it would be necessary for me to write to Victoria at once for a Temporary Certificate.

We will greatly appreciate it if you can let us know definitely, at an early date, just what your decisions are as this move necessitates closing our home and disposing of some stock and it will soon be Sept.

Hoping that we may hear from you as soon as possible, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Nellie Campbell

The Director, Indian Health Services, Department of National Health and Welfare, Ottawa, Canada.

Attention: H. A. Procter, M.D.

Further to our conversation regarding medical matters in this Agency, it is recommended that a full-time Field Matron be established at Kitkatla Indian Reserve located some 42 miles south west of Prince Rupert. The population of this village according to our latest figures is 336. This village is fairly isolated during the stormy winter months when a large percentage of the people are usually in residence. It is estimated that 80% of the population are in residence for seven to eight months each year. There is a complete exodus of the population to the canneries for the summer months and the village is deserted. The physical plant at this village consists of a 40 year old one-room day school and an ancient mission house, the ownership of which has never been completely clarified as between the Church and the Department. There is an urgent need for a new two-room school and teacherage at this village and it is suggested that when these plans are drawn the new plant should include a dispensary and nurse's quarters.

If two unmarried teachers are secured for this school this coming fall, it is possible that a Field Matron could be accommodated for this winter though it would make for cramped quarters in the present teacherage (Mission House). Rather than have your Branch build a separate dispensary and nurse's quarters, it is recommended that conference ensue between your Branch and the Indian Affairs Branch as to the aforementioned combination unit which should adequately serve the needs of this village for many years. It is also of importance that communications be made available from this village to the Medical Officer, Dr. Macdonald, and this can best, in my opinion, be brought about by the installation of a radiophone on a rental basis similar to that now projected for Port Simpson and the Nass River.
This village has been neglected in the past from a medical point of view and the tuberculosis incidence is, in my opinion, higher than in almost any other village of comparable size in the Agency.

cc. Dr. J. A. Macdonald.

Enclosed please find resignation of Miss Anne Schmidt as teacher at the Kitkatla Indian Day School effective June 30th. Acceptance of this resignation is recommended.

Miss Schmidt was in the office today and has told me something of conditions under which she has worked this last winter. She is quite definitely below par physically and is near a nervous breakdown. Miss Meier, Field Matron, is teaching the school at Kitkatla today to enable Miss Schmidt to come in and consult a doctor regarding her health.

The Indians are leaving the village very rapidly and I have instructed Miss Schmidt that if she considers her health endangered by continuing, she may close the school on or after the 16th inst. I have discussed the question of renting suitable premises or of repairing the present school building with Miss Schmidt, Miss Meier and the Chief Councillor and other representatives of the village. The only possible building that could be secured is the Church Army hall and I understand that one wall of this building is in an unsafe condition.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 8th instant, your file 168-18-1, asking if a nomination has been received for Kitkatla School, I would advise that this, in common with other Anglican Schools in this Province, has not yet opened for the lack of qualified teachers. I am, however, asking Mr. Gillett if he will enquire of Bishop Rix if he has any suitable person in view, although, of course, as you are aware, the Bishop is quite anxious to nominate persons entirely unqualified for these positions.

I have written to the Unemployment Insurance Commission Officers at Vancouver, Victoria, and New Westminster, asking them to refer to me persons who might register with them and have the necessary qualifications for these positions. I am hopeful that this will produce some results. I believe there are also quite a number of white schools in the Province that are unable to open for lack of teachers.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Mr. R. Shearman, teacher of the Kitkatla Indian Day School, in which he strongly protests against the decision of the Department to only operate the Indian day schools for a nine-month period during the academic year 1940-41.

Due to conditions at present confronting us it was found necessary to make a drastic reduction in our appropriation for Indian education for the current fiscal year. As a result it was only found possible to provide salary for teachers of Indian day schools for a nine-month period. In circular letter issued to you some months ago we suggested that the day schools be closed for the month of September. However, we have no objection if the day schools are kept open during that month but closed for another month between September 1, 1940, and March 31, 1941. Our reason for making this statement is that, as you are aware, the fiscal year runs from April 1 to March 31 and as the day schools have now been open for three months of the current fiscal year, namely, April, May and June, there remains in our appropriation only sufficient funds to pay for six months' salary between September 1 and March 31.

While it is regretted that this decision involves a loss of salary to Mr. Shearman you should point out to him that all Indian day school teachers in Canada will be affected in a similar manner. You might advise me later whether the Kitkatla School will be closed for September or for some other month.

Yours truly,

Mr. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.

April 28th, 1940

To the Secretary
Department for Indian Affairs
Ottawa. (The Kitkatla School)

Dear Sir,

I have been informed by the Indian Agent for this Skeena Agency, that schools will be closed until Oct 1st. On this Reserve it is a grave injustice. On May 9th, 1940 Captain Barry, the Indian School Inspector on his visit here, took this matter up with me. We went through figures together and he said that he should not report that this School be closed. I had 23 at School last September, & doubtless this Sep shall have more. My heart & interest is centred upon helping all Indians in any way I can from day to day. For many years, and even before Captain Barry was appointed Inspector, I have always had worthy reports on my work, and kindly cooperation with the natives.

Further I have had schools with over 60 children & worked them satisfactorily since founded on the one salary of $90. There are schools
with not so many children, where there are two teachers, and cases where teachers with far less experience than I have, getting $120 monthly.

It would be a precious loss to me if the months salary of $90. Were I away, an isolated island Reserve in the Pacific, and have two grown girls, one just starting her career as nurse & the other finishing Grade XII at High School, Vancouver. This is of great moment, for I have to sacrifice much as it is for them; what I would do, at the loss of a month's salary I do not know.

I trust you will kindly give consideration to my school to be kept open to Sep; years ago I have opened as early as Sep 6th, with a satisfactory attendance.

Thanking you in anticipation for a reply,

I beg to remain

Your obedient servant

B. Shearman
Dear Sir,

Now my wife and I are transferred from Kitwanga (Baltin Agency) to Kiskatla (Steena Agency) to take over. Sep. 2, 1924, I beg to ask of you a favour. We have no mail service at the isolated place of Kiskatla, and must depend upon natives getting mail on an order from me, when they go in to Rupert. The same thing applied when we were there from 1924 to 1934.

To save unnecessary delay and loss, will you kindly forward all cheques - due from Kitwanga and onward from Kiskatla, to the Manager of the Bank of Commerce

PRINCE RUPERT B.C.

Thanking you in anticipation

Yours respectfully,

B. Shearman

Dear Sir:

Are any of your Indian schools in this part of Canada - the Okanagan Valley of British Columbia - require qualified teachers?

At the moment, I am in charge of a school in New B.C., but would prefer a change after Christmas if that is reasonably possible.

I have a list. Cases Humane, B.C. Certificate, also a list. Cases Manitoba Humane. I attended summer school in Victoria in 1927 and in 1928.

If I took charge of one of your schools, it would be necessary that I accept one where a residence is available, as my position as a teacher involves the responsibility of taking care of my two-year-old daughter "home-schooled" for my first year old daughter over 3 years old.

This is a little of curiosity rather than one of application, until I know more of conditions in any of the districts where a school might be available. Could I have particulars regarding wages, fuel available, etc. of any nearby situations you may have?

Sir,

Ottawa, Sept. 1, 1922.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 31st ultimo, with reference to the salary of the teacher of the Kitikatla Indian Day School.

On looking up this matter, I find that the return was received in the Department on August 8th, and the cheque for the salary for the months of April and May, amounting to $200, was mailed from here on August 11th. Through oversight, this cheque was sent in care of Mr. Agent Foughner, Bella Coola, instead of to you. Possibly he has already forwarded the cheque to Mr. Coffin. If not, you might communicate with Mr. Foughner and have him send it forward.

Cheque 1428 for $30.00 in payment of the bonus due Mr. Coffin for the months of April and May was sent to you on the 26th ultimo.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Sir:-

I beg to transmit herewith, school return on the Kitkatla Indian Day School for the quarter ended March 31st, 1934.

It will be noted that the school did not open till Jan. 29th owing to the fact that the teacher was marooned in Prince Rupert and could not get back to Kitkatla on account of very stormy weather, although several attempts were made. Altogether 14 school days were lost. In order to make up part of the time extra school hours were put in each day.

Under the circumstances which were entirely unavoidable, I would recommend that the salary of the teacher be paid in full.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Collison,

"The average Indian parent, not being

excuse themselves by saying that they do not know

present, there is none."
Ottawa, March 14th, 1927.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report for the month of January, last, on your inspection of the Kitkatla Indian Day School, in which you recommend that a bell be supplied in order that the Indian parents, who do not possess timepieces, can have their children in school on time, I beg to say that the Department will approve of the supplying of a suitable bell for the purpose. You should obtain prices from several dealers for the supplying of a school tower bell of approximately 22" in diameter, with the necessary bell rope, etc. We are not aware as to the names of the firms in British Columbia from which a bell of this type can be obtained, but, no doubt, any school supply house will keep same in stock. When this bell arrives, you should have a suitable stand erected near the school on which to place the bell. The cost of the bell and the erection of a stand for same should be kept down to the lowest possible point. Please forward properly certified, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

You should give the matter of the purchase of this bell and its installation your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C.
Ottawa, March 14, 1927.

Gentlemen:

We understand that you have on hand a school bell ordered by Mr. C. A. Arthur, Indian Agent, Brocket, Alta., which order he subsequently cancelled. I have to request that you will arrange to ship this bell to Mr. W. E. Collison, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C., for the use of the Kitkatla Indian Day School. Please prepay freight charges, and forward your account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the bell, with receipt for freight charges attached, to Mr. Collison. We are informing Mr. Collison of the order having been placed with you to ship this bell, and requesting him, upon receipt of the bell, to certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

I shall be pleased to have an acknowledgment of this order, stating date when shipment of the bell goes forward.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Messrs. J. H. Ashdown Co. Ltd.,
Calgary,
Alta.
Ottawa, March 14, 1927.

Sir:

Referring to our letter to you of today's date, authorizing you to purchase a bell for the use of the Kitkatla Indian Day School, I now have to request that you will cancel this order. We find that a duplicate order was placed for a bell for another school and there is consequently a bell on hand at Calgary which can be forwarded to Kitkatla. We are, therefore, giving the necessary instructions to have this bell shipped addressed to you at Prince Rupert, and when it arrives, you should arrange to have it taken to the school and a suitable stand erected near the school on which it could be placed. You should forward properly receipted vouchers for any expenditure incurred in freighting this bell to the school and in the erection of the stand for same.

We are ordering this bell from the J. H. Ashdown Co., Ltd., Calgary, and the account covering the cost of same will be sent to you. Upon receipt of the bell, you will be good enough to certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

I beg to transmit herewith, requisition for seed and garden implements received from Mr. B. Shearman, school teacher of Kitkatla.

Mr. Shearman will remain at Kitkatla during the summer vacation, July and August, and intends improving the land around his residence and that of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 3rd, 1929.

Sir:

Referring to your reports for the months of September and October, last, on the Kitkatla Indian Day School relative to the condition of the present school building and the need of new desks, I have to say with reference to the providing of a new school building that the Department is not making provision in its Estimates for the next fiscal year for the funds required for this purpose. We are, however, providing an amount to erect a teacher's residence.

Relative to the supplying of the new desks required, I have to say that you may place an order with the Tait Pipe & Foundry Co., Ltd., Vancouver, to supply the sizes and number of each size of single school desks and front and rear seats required. For your information I may say that this firm manufactures desks in the following sizes:

| Size No. | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| No. 1    | Adults      |
| No. 2    | Pupils 15 to 16 Years |
| No. 3    | 12 to 16   |
| No. 4    | 9 to 13    |
| No. 5    | 6 to 10    |
| No. 6    | 4 to 7     |

It would be well to consult the teacher and ascertain the number of desks of each size that would be satisfactory to accommodate the pupils. If the desks are arranged in rows, there should be a row of the same size desks with a front and rear seat. You should arrange for the purchase and delivery of the number of single desks required at an early date.

The price charged by the above firm should be F.O.B. nearest shipping point to the school, and you should request them, in forwarding their account to you, which should be in duplicate, to include the freight charges and sales tax in the cost of the desks. When the desks have been delivered, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

W. B. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert,
B.C.
